Article title: La Plata, Berisso and Ensenada under scrutiny: satellites reveal terrifying critical levels of pollution that exceed recommended limits
Full article text:
Climate TRACE reveals that Greater La Plata exceeds critical air pollution thresholds. PM2.5 and NO2 threaten the health of thousands of residents.

Author of the entry
By The Graphic Mail
Date of entry
27/01/2026
La Plata, Berisso and Ensenada under scrutiny: satellites reveal critical levels of pollution exceeding recommended limits. 13
Greater La Plata , which includes the municipalities of La Plata, Berisso and Ensenada, was listed as one of the most polluted areas in Argentina, according to data from the international monitoring platform Climate TRACE , which uses artificial intelligence and satellite technology to track greenhouse gas emissions globally.

Contents in the news
The system, co-founded by former US Vice President Al Gore , identified the petrochemical hub , the transport sector, and solid waste management as the main sources of air pollution in the region, posing serious risks to the public health of the inhabitants.

Technical analysis reveals that pollutants such as fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2) far exceed the thresholds recommended by international organizations, exposing the population to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases and lung cancer .

Three sectors responsible for the pollutant emissions profile
La Plata, Berisso and Ensenada under scrutiny: satellites reveal critical levels of pollution exceeding recommended limits.

The Greater La Plata region presents a complex environmental scenario, dominated by three main sectors that contribute significantly to the deterioration of air quality .

First, the petrochemical complex encompassing La Plata, Berisso, and Ensenada, identified as a hotspot for carbon dioxide and other toxic gas emissions, represents one of the main environmental threats. This industrial complex houses the YPF refinery and distillery, steel companies, and thermoelectric power plants, among other high-impact facilities.

La Plata, Berisso and Ensenada under scrutiny: satellites reveal critical pollution levels exceeding recommended limits 1415

The second factor is the transportation sector , which shows sustained growth in its emissions. Data from August 2025 showed a year-on-year increase of 3.60% in overall emissions from the transportation sector, a trend that is replicated in densely populated urban areas like the capital of Buenos Aires province, where the growing vehicle fleet exacerbates the situation. According to information published by La Plata CONICET , more than 57 vehicles per day were added to the city's vehicle fleet in 2017.

Garbage collection in Berisso, Cagliardi's management is a disaster 3

The management of municipal solid waste completes the picture of polluting sources, contributing significantly to the region's overall emissions profile.

The invisible threat: microscopic particles with devastating impact
La Plata, Berisso and Ensenada under scrutiny: satellites reveal critical levels of pollution exceeding recommended limits.

Fine particulate matter (PM2.5) is the most concerning pollutant for human health. These are particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometers, invisible to the naked eye, which come mainly from vehicle emissions, industrial activity, fires, and wood burning.

The danger of these particles lies in their microscopic size, which allows them to evade the body's natural defenses. According to the technical documentation analyzed, these particles are "capable of penetrating deep into the lungs and bloodstream, causing heart disease, asthma, lung cancer, and serious respiratory problems . "


Recent research expands the list of health problems associated with PM2.5 exposure, including kidney disease, dementia, Parkinson's disease, and pregnancy complications. International studies cited by ABC News link air pollution to approximately 9 million premature deaths annually worldwide.


Nitrogen dioxide (NO2) , another key pollutant monitored in La Plata, directly affects the respiratory health of the population and is a fundamental component in the formation of urban smog that can be seen on the city's horizon.

Satellite technology reveals the journey of pollution
La Plata, Berisso and Ensenada under scrutiny: satellites reveal critical levels of pollution exceeding recommended limits. 14

One of Climate TRACE 's most innovative tools allows you to visualize so-called "pollution plumes ," animated representations that show how particulate matter generated by industrial sources travels with the wind from its origin to inhabited areas.

According to information from Radio La Plata , the platform released a map showing the plume of pollution generated by the emissions being carried by the wind, directly affecting nearby communities.


The system uses data from approximately 300 satellites and more than 30,000 monitoring stations, processed using artificial intelligence to identify emissions at the individual facility level. This unprecedented granularity allows researchers to observe how specific power plants or refineries contribute to pollution that directly affects neighborhoods and homes in La Plata, Berisso, and Ensenada.

Local studies confirm the structural challenge
La Plata, Berisso and Ensenada under scrutiny: satellites reveal critical levels of pollution exceeding recommended limits.

Research conducted by the National University of La Plata (UNLP) and CONICET has provided relevant data on the evolution of pollution in the region. According to a publication by CONICET La Plata , fellow Daniela Giuliani presented a doctoral study on air pollution that included analyses in three zones: industrial, urban, and residential.

The results are conclusive: particulate matter levels in the industrial zone exceed those in the urban zone, and both of these are higher than those in the residential zone. However, the most alarming finding comes from the comparison with international standards. While a percentage of the measurements comply with Buenos Aires regulations, 79% of the annual average particulate matter levels in the air of Greater La Plata exceed the maximum limits recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) .


Previous studies have indicated temporary or one-off decreases in industrial air pollution in previous years. However, these same studies warn that air quality remains a constant and structural challenge for the city.


One positive aspect is the UNLP's forest resources, which absorb a large portion of the carbon emissions generated by the institution itself. However, this mitigation effort is insufficient given the volume of massive industrial emissions from the petrochemical complex, which keeps the region's overall carbon balance in negative territory.

Global context and worrying trends
The situation in Greater La Plata is framed within a global context that shows no signs of significant improvement. Global greenhouse gas emissions continued to rise in 2025, with an estimated increase of 0.55% compared to 2024.

The transport sector represents one of the biggest challenges, with a 3.6% increase in its emissions worldwide, putting additional pressure on densely populated urban centers like Greater La Plata.

Climate TRACE: radical transparency in emissions
La Plata, Berisso and Ensenada under scrutiny: satellites reveal critical levels of pollution exceeding recommended limits.

Climate TRACE (Tracking Real-time Atmospheric Carbon Emissions) is a global coalition made up of NGOs, technology companies and universities, co-founded by Al Gore , former US Vice President and Nobel Peace Prize laureate.

According to WattTime , the project began in 2019 with a grant from Google.org to monitor emissions from power plants from space. Climate TRACE was formally launched in July 2020 and now brings together more than 100 collaborating organizations.


The platform uses artificial intelligence and satellite data to monitor emissions worldwide at the individual asset level. Its goal is to provide detailed and independent data to accelerate climate action, limit global temperature rise to 1.5°C, and foster more sustainable development.

In September 2025, Climate TRACE expanded its system to track not only greenhouse gases , but also fine particulate matter pollutants that cause millions of deaths annually, monitoring more than 660 million pollution sources globally, as reported by TechCrunch .

Implications for public policy
The region's capacity to mitigate these emissions on a large scale is limited, positioning Greater La Plata as a key observation area for the design of environmental policies at the provincial and national levels.

The availability of accurate and up-to-date data on emissions at the individual facility level represents a fundamental tool for authorities, investors and communities to demand accountability from those responsible for pollution.


The Buenos Aires air quality regulations, amended in 2018, incorporated the regulation of PM2.5, which was not included in the original 1996 document. However, experts point out that the permitted levels have not been updated and urgently need to be to align with international standards.

The pending challenge
The data presented by Climate TRACE removes the abstraction of the air pollution problem , offering concrete visualizations of pollution plumes moving from the petrochemical hub to residential areas, of invisible particles that threaten the health of thousands of inhabitants, and of an environmental challenge that exceeds local mitigation efforts.

Satellite technology and artificial intelligence have made the invisible visible, providing the community with tools to understand the magnitude of the problem and demand concrete solutions from the relevant authorities and the industries responsible for emissions.


The question that emerges from this technical analysis is clear: with irrefutable scientific evidence on the levels of pollution and their specific sources, what measures will local and provincial authorities implement to protect the health of the inhabitants of Greater La Plata?

Article title: Caatinga biome could account for half of Brazil's carbon sequestration, study indicates.
Full article text: From 2015 to 2022, the Caatinga was responsible for almost 50% of all carbon capture in Brazil, according to a study published in the scientific journal Science of the Total Environment . Despite being a less "famous" biome compared to the Amazon and the Cerrado, the semi-arid Northeast has proven to be an ally in climate regulation and in meeting the net-zero emissions targets assumed by Brazil in the Paris Agreement. The dynamic is simple: for much of the year, the vegetation remains dry, but when the rains arrive, the Caatinga enters an accelerated growth cycle, capturing more CO₂ from the atmosphere and functioning as a "green lung" in the middle of the semi-arid region. The research was conducted by scientists from São Paulo State University (Unesp) and international collaborators. It investigated the impact of carbon removal on all Brazilian biomes. The authors' methodology compares data from SEEG (System for Estimating Emissions and Removals of Greenhouse Gases) with figures from Climate TRACE – an international consortium that uses satellites and artificial intelligence to monitor emissions in real time. The researchers also analyzed precipitation data and chlorophyll fluorescence, an indicator of photosynthesis. The result was as follows: although the Amazon maintains a carbon absorption equilibrium point, the Caatinga showed growth in photosynthetic activity in rainier years, which significantly increased its carbon sequestration capacity. "If deforestation is effectively controlled and anthropogenic disturbances reduced, Brazil could not only achieve net-zero emissions, but become a net carbon sink," the authors conclude. Recent studies, however, detail that the Caatinga has already lost approximately 8.6 million hectares of native vegetation between 1985 and 2023 – equivalent to 14% of its original coverage, according to data from the National Institute for Space Research (Inpe). The biome is home to more than 3,000 plant species and about 1,800 animal species. Researcher and chemist Marília Goulart argues that the Caatinga biome is resilient, but this should not lead to negligence on the part of public authorities. "It is necessary to learn from its survival mechanisms."

Article title: Study reveals the importance of the Caatinga biome for carbon sequestration in the Brazilian context.
Full article text: The release of greenhouse gases by human activities is the main cause of climate change. Gases such as carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), or nitrous oxide (N2O), for example, have the ability to retain heat in the atmosphere, causing it to warm and altering the planet's climate patterns. Quantifying and understanding the origins of these emissions is, therefore, a fundamental step in guiding the development of public policies and actions that seek to reduce these releases and mitigate their effects on the global climate. In recent years, nations, economic sectors, and organizations have been developing inventories to document the volume and profile of productive activities responsible for these releases, with the aim of minimizing them and offsetting this impact. In general, the amount of gases emitted into the atmosphere is a balance formed by the volume emitted from activities minus the carbon that is recovered, for example, by natural activities such as plant photosynthesis. An article produced by researchers from the Faculty of Agricultural and Veterinary Sciences (FCAV) at Unesp, on the Jaboticabal campus, investigated the impact of carbon removal on the Brazilian greenhouse gas inventory and pointed to the central role of the Caatinga in this process. According to the study, in some years the northeastern biome, despite occupying approximately 10% of the national territory, accounted for almost 50% of all carbon capture carried out in the country. The analysis conducted by researcher Luís Miguel da Costa, alongside Professor Newton La Scala Jr., shows that the Caatinga surpasses other biomes more celebrated for their environmental services, such as the Amazon and the Cerrado – at least in the period between 2015 and 2022, the time interval investigated by the research team. The work was published in the journal Science of the Total Environment . The research compared data from two of the main sources of information on greenhouse gas emissions and removals available for Brazil today: the Greenhouse Gas Emissions Estimation System (SEEG), coordinated by Brazilian institutions such as the Climate Observatory, and Climate TRACE , an international consortium that uses satellite imagery and artificial intelligence to monitor emissions across the planet in near real-time. In addition to focusing on Brazilian biomes, the study also included the analysis of satellite data on precipitation and chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF). Chlorophyll fluorescence is a direct indicator of the photosynthetic activity of vegetation; that is, the more intense the SIF, the greater the sequestration of atmospheric carbon by plants. According to the study's authors, what occurs in the Caatinga is that the increased availability of water during periods of abundant rainfall is reflected in a very positive response from the photosynthetic process. “We had previously conducted a specific study on the SIF (Synthetic Factor Index) for all six Brazilian biomes. In the Amazon, for example, we found that there is practically a plateau, a maximum level. However, when we analyzed photosynthetic activity in relation to precipitation in the Caatinga, we observed a very large increase in the SIF in those years when rainfall exceeds the biome's averages,” explains the researcher. According to the data presented now, Scala Jr. says that the Amazon remains an immense carbon reservoir, whose preservation is fundamental. The Caatinga, on the other hand, caught the researchers' attention by demonstrating a significant capacity to capture carbon, related to its vegetation's ability to respond positively to certain environmental factors, such as rainfall. "These are different characteristics, but equally important," affirms the professor from the Jaboticabal campus. The rapid regrowth of plants is a unique attribute that makes the biome function as a significant carbon sink, even during relatively short periods of improved climate. The dry vegetation, which predominates for much of the year, enters a cycle of accelerated growth as soon as the rains arrive, sequestering large amounts of CO₂ from the atmosphere, about 40% of the country's removals, according to studies already conducted in the region. Deforestation is the main culprit behind Brazilian emissions. As the authors of the article explain, Brazilian emissions are entirely associated with changes in land use and occupation. Agriculture emerges as the second largest emitting sector, followed by the energy sector. According to official data from SEEG itself, gross Brazilian GHG emissions in 2023 totaled approximately 2.3 billion tons of CO₂ equivalent (or 2.3 GtCO₂e), representing a reduction of about 12% compared to the previous year, when the total was 2.6 GtCO₂e [ see image below ]. The term "equivalent," in this case, is used when the calculation refers to all gases that cause the greenhouse effect, in terms equivalent to CO₂. Recently, official data released by the DETER system , a tool from the National Institute for Space Research (INPE) that monitors changes in the country's forest cover, indicated a 33% reduction in deforestation in the first half of 2023, compared to 2022, and a 21% increase in the Cerrado during the same period. Most of the deforestation in the biome occurs in the deforestation arc, near the Amazon, and also in the region called Matopiba (the northern portion of the biome that encompasses the states of Maranhão, Tocantins, Piauí, and Bahia). Net emissions from land use and forests, that is, the deforestation balance, reached approximately 1.8 GtCO₂e in the 1990s. However, due to strengthened environmental enforcement, this emissions balance fell to approximately 0.2 GtCO₂e in 2012. After that year, emissions began to rise again, placing Brazil, at best, as the last among the ten largest global emitters in this category. The increasing fires and deforestation in areas of both the Amazon and the Cerrado have helped to boost these numbers. Comparison between inventories reveals a difference of up to 1 GtCO₂e. The comparison made by the Jaboticabal group between the two inventories, SEEG and Climate TRACE, revealed significant differences in the estimates of carbon removal in the Brazilian land use and forestry sector. In some years, the divergence reaches 1 billion tons of CO₂ equivalent, which represents approximately 44% of all national emissions in 2023. “Climate TRACE is able to see the climatic variations on vegetation more clearly. However, both are important, depending on the answers one intends to obtain,” explains Costa. Methodological differences and the profile of the data used by each tool help explain the difference in the numbers. The researcher clarifies that while Climate TRACE uses artificial intelligence algorithms and remote sensing data in its calculations, SEEG considers information such as land use type, the extent of forested areas, and deforestation data. However, the Brazilian inventory does not dynamically incorporate the direct effects of climate variations on vegetation. The TRACE methodology is also based on emission factors defined by the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change), a UN body that publishes periodic reports on the state of climate change on the planet and consolidates global research on the subject. According to the researchers, this methodological difference explains why the international system identified significant increases in carbon removal in years with higher rainfall, as occurred in the Caatinga between 2021 and 2022. During this period, SIF data corroborate the significant increase in photosynthetic activity in the semi-arid region, which was reflected in the jump in carbon removal estimates in the international database. SEEG, in turn, presents more stable estimates over the years, as it does not react directly to this climate variability. “The important difference is that in the case of Climate Trace, when rain falls on a specific static forest quadrant, the biomass in that area increases, and it has sufficient sensitivity to capture this increase. SEEG, on the other hand, captures important agricultural activities, such as liming, a soil correction strategy practiced by rural producers that is a significant source of emissions,” explains La Scala Jr. The information, recorded by Climate Trace, that the Caatinga was responsible for 48% of all gross carbon removal recorded in Brazil in 2022 highlights a surprising contribution for a biome that historically receives less investment in conservation and monitoring. It is also a paradigm shift in relation to the common perception of the Caatinga, often seen as a region poor in biodiversity and with a low capacity to provide ecosystem services. Different methodologies, but both necessary. The comparison between SEEG and Climate TRACE also highlights the importance of advancing the integration of methodologies. Each system has strengths: SEEG is recognized for its transparency, data traceability, and alignment with international climate reporting standards. Climate TRACE, on the other hand, stands out for its more dynamic and responsive recording of vegetation behavior. Despite their distinct approaches, the two systems show convergence in general emission patterns in some regions, such as the Amazon. However, in other areas—such as the Caatinga—Climate TRACE detects significant net carbon removals, which do not appear with the same clarity in SEEG. These divergences highlight the need for harmonization between methodologies and reinforce the value of complementary studies such as that of the Unesp researchers, with multiple data sources. While the entire Brazilian biome plays a significant role in carbon removal—including the much-ailed Atlantic Forest—the data leaves no doubt about the strategic importance of the Caatinga as a carbon sink in the Brazilian context. For researchers at UNESP in Jaboticabal, these results reinforce the urgency of public policies focused on the conservation and recovery of native vegetation in the Caatinga. Such actions can significantly increase Brazil's contribution to removing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere, while simultaneously promoting the sustainable development of local communities in semi-arid regions. "In terms of public policy, it is important to develop ways to bring water to the region, even considering carbon sequestration," says Newton La Scala Jr. The data obtained, the scientists argue, pave the way for new investigations into the mechanisms of carbon sequestration in semi-arid environments and their response to climate change. "The continuity and improvement of monitoring, with integration between different systems, will be essential to refine estimates and guide effective mitigation actions," the study authors argue.

Article title: Cambodia’s EV success hinges on training and skills development
Full article text: The Cambodian government has set ambitious 2030 targets that will see 800,000 electric vehicles (EVs)—cars, motorcycles and tuk tuk on Cambodia’s roads. This will help clean up Cambodia’s air, contribute to the fight against global heating and reduce the country’s reliance on imported oil; and as a new EnergyLab study shows, it will also create thousands of new jobs and skills across the Kingdom. To meet Cambodia’s goals, many more EV options must be available to meet the different economic, design and practical requirements that are currently met by petrol- and diesel-powered vehicles. These new cars and motorbikes must be enticing enough. Can an electric bike ever be cool enough to replace the loud and flashy bikes currently favoured by the Kingdom’s teenagers? Rugged enough to handle rural roads in the rainy season? Efficient enough to travel the country without fear of being unable to recharge? What makes a bike attractive to female students or retired aunties? International experience suggests that this is certainly possible. Almost one in five cars sold in 2023 was electric, with the global EV stock reaching 40 million vehicles. In China, 30 percent of motorbikes sold in 2023 were also electric. But as of November 2024, Cambodia only had 6,540 registered EVs; it’s clear that the task of getting almost 800,000 new vehicles on the road is real. This is important because according to Climate TRACE, vehicles on Cambodia’s roads contributed two million tonnes of Co2e in 2024, which is four times more than the country’s airports. It is clear that EVs running on clean energy will have a positive impact. Achieving Cambodia’s EV goal will also require many new technical and service workers, with staff needing to be trained across the country. There are currently about 150 local technicians with any EV training in Cambodia, and EnergyLab’s report shows this will need to grow significantly, to at least 15,000 EV assembly workers, engineers, technicians, service advisers and battery specialists required. Government projections on EV-related jobs are even higher. This offers great potential for developing new skills and well-paying jobs, and EnergyLab’s report highlights the many opportunities that exist to support the nationwide technical and vocational education and training (TVET) system. By adding EV repair and maintenance skills to the nation’s many technicians’ extraordinary ability to keep cars and bikes of all ages and conditions running, more people will be confident in buying an EV. Additional skills also need to be developed to support the increase in EVs. Most notably, the development of a broad network of charging stations, ideally utilising solar power to further incentivise the uptake of EVs by lowering operating costs. Indeed, the lack of charging infrastructure remains a major barrier to overcome; Vietnam has over 150,000 charging stations, while Cambodia has fewer than 100 public options. Recent government guidelines on charging stations are an important step, and as more stations are built they will need well-trained local staff who can ensure that chargers are running whenever needed, across the entire country. Households can now install up to 10kw home solar systems and this is more than enough for cars and bikes to be charged during the day for free, or at any convenient time if coupled with battery storage. And with the ability of a solar and battery to remove petrol costs, the running costs of an electric car become even more attractive. With suitable financing support to help with the initial installation costs, Cambodians across the country can feel more confident that adopting a more electric lifestyle will not be a financial burden. With such ambitious EV adoption targets, the government is clearly signalling that the future of road travel in Cambodia will be electric; and 2030 is very close indeed. All of these new vehicles will drive demand for new skills, the updating of existing ones, and it will be key that the Kingdom’s TVET schools can offer the necessary classes. A future with more EVs being driven along more rural roads across Cambodia, supported by a network of solar-charging stations, is certainly exciting. But this will only be possible with a large number of high-skilled mechanics, charging station technicians, vehicle assembly engineers and all of the other ancillary jobs.

Article title: Climate TRACE: The organization that records greenhouse gas emissions worldwide – Data for Greece
Full article text: A few weeks ago, experts issued a new warning about the critical state our planet is in. Seven of the nine “planetary boundaries” have been crossed , they said, and they urged governments to listen to science. One of these long-overdue planetary limits is the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which is largely due to the continued use of fossil fuels. However, in order for scientists to set realistic reduction targets and to be able to clearly monitor progress towards achieving them, it is necessary to collect and analyze reliable data regarding the sources of origin and the amount of greenhouse gases emitted by each region of the planet. In this field, the Climate TRACE (Climate Tracking Real-time Atmospheric Carbon Emissions) organization stands out as one of the most innovative tools worldwide. What is Climate TRACE? Climate TRACE is an international collaboration of scientists, technology providers and organizations, created with the aim of providing an independent and accurate mapping of greenhouse gas emissions across the planet. Using over 300 satellites, 11,000 sensors and numerous other data sources, and leveraging technologies such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, the platform maps greenhouse gas emissions at the country, industry and even individual facility level. The result is an unprecedented digital archive, which by 2024 will include more than 660 million facilities/emission sources around the world – from power plants and industrial plants to ports and airports. On the organization's interactive map , the user can find data by region, industry and gas type (CO₂, methane, etc.) for the year they are interested in. In addition, they can monitor the GWP (Global Warming Potential) index over a 20 or 100 year time horizon. What's happening in Greece? For 2025 up to July, carbon dioxide emissions in Greece reached 44.57 million tons, of which: 46.93% came from transport, communications and road traffic 21.41% from electricity generation units 10.9% from industry 9.81% from residential properties 8.3% from fossil fuel processing 2.43% from the agricultural sector 0.22% from mineral extraction Why it matters Climate TRACE's contribution is particularly important, as it offers for the first time an independent, global and transparent record of greenhouse gas emissions, without time delays. This gives governments, scientists and citizens the ability to know who is polluting, where and how much. In Greece, the climate law 4936/2022 provides: 55% reduction in emissions by 2030 (compared to 1990) Climate neutrality by 2050 It is worth noting that in 2023, Greece accounted for 2.3% of EU net greenhouse gas emissions and achieved a net emission reduction of 48.5% from 2005 to 2023, a percentage higher than the EU average reduction of 30.5% over the same period.

Article title: New Climate TRACE Tool Maps Air Pollution Plumes Over Athens and 2,500 Cities Worldwide
Full article text: A new online tool launched by Climate TRACE reveals, in unprecedented detail, how industrial facilities and power plants worldwide expose billions of people to dangerous air pollution. The tool, released at Climate Week NYC, uses atmospheric modeling to make visible the plumes of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) — a deadly pollutant linked to nearly nine million deaths annually. According to Climate TRACE, 1.6 billion people across more than 2,500 urban areas are breathing in pollution from facilities that are also major contributors to the climate crisis. For the first time, the public can see how emissions from specific sources — including power plants, refineries, mines, shipping ports, and heavy manufacturing sites — disperse into surrounding neighborhoods over a 24-hour period. The data is drawn from Climate TRACE’s global database of more than 660 million greenhouse gas emission sources and modeled by Carnegie Mellon University’s CREATE Lab. The project identifies “super emitters,” facilities ranked among the top 10% of PM2.5 polluters worldwide. These sources account for a disproportionate share of pollution exposure: of the 1.6 billion people living in plumes, 900 million are affected by super emitters. Greece is among the countries with several cities now mapped. The tool shows plumes from 20 emitting sources around the capital of Athens on July 3, 2024, a day representing prevailing conditions. Ten of those facilities are classified as super emitters, underscoring the high risk of exposure for residents of one of Europe’s most densely populated capitals. Viewers can also look at plumes in Thessaloniki, Patras, Chalkida, Chania, Heraklion, and Volos. “Facilities that burn fossil fuels are the overwhelmingly dominant source of heat-trapping pollution that is driving the climate crisis — by using the sky as if it were an open sewer,” said Climate TRACE co-founder and former U.S. Vice President Al Gore in a press release by Climate TRACE. “The particulate air pollution they also create falls downwind into surrounding neighborhoods and is causing the deaths of 8.7 million people per year.” Globally, the cities with the largest exposed populations include Karachi, Guangzhou, Seoul, New York, and Dhaka. Together, the top 10 urban areas account for more than 162 million people living under harmful plumes. The coalition behind Climate TRACE brings together AI specialists, researchers, and NGOs, with support from organizations such as Carnegie Mellon’s CREATE Lab, Johns Hopkins University, Duke University, RMI, WattTime, TransitionZero, Global Fishing Watch, and former Vice President Gore himself. Climate TRACE says it tracks nearly all sources of human-caused PM2.5 pollution, but has only visualized the flow of that pollution for power plants, heavy manufacturing sites, ports, refineries, and mines in the 2,572 urban areas where they exist. It adds that it is “important to note that the tool does not represent all sources of PM2.5 in these urban areas. There are many other sources of this type of air pollution — from fires, to dust, and more — that are common, particularly in cities around the world.” The tool is designed for policymakers, journalists, researchers, and communities to identify hotspots and push for action, says Climate TRACE. While the current version focuses on stationary industrial sources, future updates plan to expand coverage to other major contributors, including transport and residential fuel use. The interactive maps and facility-level data are freely available at ClimateTRACE.org.

Article title: Are methane emissions in India being missed?
Full article text:
What fuels landfill fires and is 84 times more potent than carbon dioxide over a 20-year period? The answer is methane. While it is an excellent fuel for kitchen stoves, CNG vehicles, and power plants, it is also busy burning the planet. Methane is generated naturally by decomposing organic matter. The same prehistoric processes that created natural gas reserves are now at work within landfills. Managing methane means not just cleaner cities but also a significant step toward our climate ambitions. 
Around 15% of India's methane emissions are from the waste sector. Unlike theagriculture or energy sectors, which require complex, long-term reforms, waste management offers immediate gains through targeted action. Crucially, the policy frameworks and incentives are already in place through national programmes such as the Swachh Bharat Mission. 
Targeted action is only possible if we know exactly where the hotspots are, but tracking an invisible gas is difficult. Historically, we have relied on models that estimate emissions by tracking incoming waste volumes and applying baseline assumptions. However, this approach depends on accurate, recurring data, which is often scarce in developing countries. Because such data are aggregated at theregional or national levels and updated infrequently, it makes pinpointing individual sources nearly impossible. 
The alternative is physical monitoring, which is even more challenging in the Indian context. Ground-level detection requires expensive equipment, regular maintenance, and constant oversight, making it logistically and technically difficult to scale. 
As technology advances, satellites are stepping into this gap. This data broadly fall into two categories: regional measurements that monitor methane over a few kilometers (frequent and useful for national trends), and fine-resolution detection that can pinpoint hotspots down to a few square meters (critical for targeted action). 
India has already taken the first steps toward this opportunity. Last year, a paper published by scientists from ISRO quantified anthropogenic methane emissions across the country using satellite data that was acquired in 2023. Based on these measurements, the study identified major dumpsites in Pirana (Ahmedabad), Deonar and Kanjurmarg (Mumbai), and a sewage outlet as significant emitters. The National Green Tribunal took these findings further, establishing a committee to conduct ground investigations at the flagged sites. 
Over the past few years, multiple new satellite missions have emerged, such as CarbonMapper's Tanager and the Space Research Organisation Netherlands (SRON) projects. These satellites provide public data covering major landfills across thecountry, including Ghazipur and Okhla in Delhi, Jawaharnagar in Hyderabad, and Dhapa in Kolkata. Platforms such as ClimateTRACE and WasteMap collate this global monitoring data, combining it with baseline statistics for advanced modeling. These newer models refine traditional calculations by integrating real-time satellite observations and updating landfill-specific estimates to reflect reality. 
Globally, satellite surveys estimate that actual landfill emissions can exceed model-based predictions by around 1.8 times. In India, city-level comparisons are difficult due to a lack of granular data on waste characteristics. Consequently, we must rely on State-level estimates from 2018 for sector-wise breakdowns, as newer public data have not yet been compiled. This discrepancy between advanced satellite observations and older State models highlights a critical information gap: we currently cannot agree on the true scale of the numbers or the location of thehotspots. 
Take Delhi as an example: its 2018 emissions inventory estimates 1.07 million tons of CO2 equivalent annually from the entire solid waste sector. Recent satellite observations, however, estimate emissions from just Ghazipur and Bhalswa alone to be between 0.85 and 0.96 million tons — almost as much as the sector's entire theoretical footprint. In Mumbai, the data offer a different perspective. While calculations suggest that the Kanjurmarg landfill accounts for 11% of the city's waste emissions, an expected number given its engineered design. However, satellite data show it to be emitting 1.05 million tons. This is almost 10 times the model's estimate and approximately half of the entire State's solid waste emissions. A similar discrepancy emerges in Gujarat: the state estimates 0.73 million tons for the entire sector, satellite observations show the landfills in Surat and Ahmedabad alone emitting between 0.60 and 0.81 million tons. 
These are not just numbers. They indicate potential leakages, accelerated methane generation, or opportunities to refine our engineered systems.. Critically, these are hazards we never tackled simply because we did not know they existed. Now, we can not only gauge the magnitude of the problem but, in the case of large landfills, also pinpoint the exact source of the leaks, allowing for precise, targeted solutions. 
Of course, these observations come with limitations. Cloud interference and complex weather dynamics mean that satellite data cannot fulfil its potential in isolation. Urban local bodies must complement these findings with ground-level insights, a step that is especially critical for the massive, unwieldy landfills of our metro cities. The real breakthrough lies in linking satellite detection with ground-level action. 
When satellites detect a methane hotspot, ground teams can immediately investigate the cause — whether it is poor waste coverage, a gas collection failure, or illegal dumping. This creates a powerful feedback loop: space-based detection guides targeted ground interventions, while ground data validate and improve satellite accuracy. Integrating other data sources beyond just methane monitoring can further enhance the efficiency of this loop. 
At open dumpsites such as Ghazipur, recording dumping and reclamation patterns provides critical insight into how human activity drives methane generation. Meanwhile, at engineered landfills such as Jawaharnagar and Kanjurmarg, infrastructure data on existing gas collection systems can help pinpoint leaks and identify hidden hotspots. Cities such as Bengaluru, with their advanced waste management systems, are well-positioned to integrate these datasets to increase transparency. 
To address this, we need coordinated action on three critical fronts: expanding satellite monitoring to cover all major waste sites, establishing on-ground validation systems in metro cities, and creating standardised data-sharing protocols between urban local bodies and oversight agencies. 
Currently, urban local bodies operate in silos, separate from the State Pollution Control Boards that oversee them. This disconnect hinders coordinated action on methane reduction. However, the revised municipal waste guidelines already envision a centralised data portal for bulk waste management, handling the wet waste that is the primary source of untreated methane. This portal could be expanded to connect with a standardised nationwide dataset for tracking emissions. Regional bodies such as the Commission for Air Quality Management (CAQM) in the NCR can oversee this monitoring, while the Swachh Bharat Mission can integrate methane targets, aligning them with other central schemes. 
This integrated approach delivers multiple co-benefits that make the investment worthwhile. Methane's potential as a fuel is already recognised in policy. Just recently, Indore has utilised the Gobardhan scheme to set up a Bio-CNG plant from its waste. 
This strategy creates a powerful ecosystem: satellites detect hotspots, ground teams investigate and fix leaks, and standardised data sharing ensures insights reach decision-makers instantly. What is needed now is coordinated implementation across these three fronts. By making data the backbone of our waste policy, we can turn one of our biggest environmental challenges into our smartest climate solution.

Article title: Global emissions rise again: Dependence on fossil fuels remains the biggest challenge
Full article text: Global greenhouse gas emissions increased in the first half of 2025, while emissions from the power sector declined. This contrast highlights that progress towards clean energy will remain limited unless global dependence on fossil fuels is reduced. Global figures: emissions increase by 0.13% Global emissions reached 31 billion tonnes of CO₂e between January and June 2025 — 0.13% more than the same period in 2024, according to data released by Climate TRACE on August 28, 2025. In June alone, global emissions stood at 5.12 billion tonnes CO₂e , up 0.29% from June 2024. Methane emissions also increased to 34.82 million tonnes — an increase of 0.49%. India's role: mixed signals Emissions from India's power sector declined by 0.8% , which is a positive sign. But overall, India's emissions increased by 0.21% , resulting in an additional 4.44 million tonnes of CO₂e . Major US share The US alone increased emissions by 48.57 million tonnes of CO₂e— an increase of 1.43% , accounting for the largest share of the global increase. This shows that America is still highly dependent on oil, gas and coal. Other sources of emissions growth Emissions from fossil fuel operations increased by 1.5% (77.65 million tonnes CO₂e). Emissions from the industry/construction sector increased by 0.3% (18.75 million tonnes), mainly from India, Vietnam, Indonesia and Brazil. Power Sector Reforms Globally, emissions from the power sector fell by 60.27 million tonnes . China posted a decline of 1.7% — the biggest contribution. International warnings and legal opinions The International Court of Justice recently said that if a government does not stop fossil fuel production, consumption, licensing or subsidies, it may be considered an “internationally wrongful act.” According to the IPCC report, if the 1.5°C temperature limit is to be achieved, emissions must peak by 2025 and be reduced by 43% by 2030 . GK facts related to the news Climate TRACE is a global coalition that includes AI experts, researchers, and former US Vice President Al Gore. CO₂e (Carbon dioxide equivalent) is a standard unit for measuring the impact of greenhouse gases. The SSP 5-8.5 climate scenario is based on peak emissions and minimal climate policy. IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) is a United Nations body that conducts scientific studies on climate change. The severity of the climate crisis is now even more evident. Countries like India, which have reduced emissions in the power sector, must now make tough policy decisions in other sectors as well. At the same time, curbing the global fossil fuel addiction is the need of the hour.

Article title: Revealed: The Irish factory with emissions so high that Al Gore put it on his naughty list
Full article text:
Mannok’s Co Cavan cement factory generates so much greenhouse gas that it is listed as Ireland’s eighth biggest emitter on Al Gore’s Climate Trace website.

The independent tracker attributed nearly 650,000 tonnes of C02 to the Ballyconnell facility in 2024 – equivalent to the electricity emissions from almost one million homes.

But, according to Cavan County Council’s first Climate Action Plan, Mannok plans to decarbonise cement production and power its facilities by building a “renewable energy valley”, including local green hydrogen production.

The company, formerly part of Seán Quinn’s empire, would not offer a spokesperson when asked for an interview about its plans, but a spokesperson for Cavan County Council said it has a “strong working relationship with Mannok and has met with and been kept briefed with regard to Mannok’s decarbonisation plans”.

“The local authority has taken account of these efforts in its Climate Action Plan,” they added.

According to the action plan: “The removal of close to half-a-million tonnes of CO2 per annum will not only have a substantial impact on the county’s emissions reduction requirements, but will also provide for vast co-benefits in the areas of employment, air quality, clean energy and economic prosperity.”

While they appear to be working to cut energy and production emissions, Mannok and the council have come under fire over a quarry application that could destroy another vital tool in the fight against climate change: Aughaweenagh Fartrin bog.

The Irish Peatland Restoration Council says raised bogs are a “unique feature of the Irish landscape” and “an important store of carbon, helping to control greenhouse gases”.

West Cavan Bogs Association’s Paddy Gilroy, a Save Ballyheady supporter, said “Cavan County Council leant over backwards to accommodate Mannok in its planning application for the quarry”.

“We made 100 submissions against this quarry,” he said. “It was completely going to obliterate our raised bogs, which are very precious.

“There’s two bogs in Cavan up to this level: Kilconny Bog in east Cavan and our bog, Aughaweenagh Fartrin bog.

“If you have a good active bog with active stagnant moss, carbon will be stored indefinitely."

Have they given up on the planning application or have they not?

Submissions to the council about the quarry application outlined concerns about the impact it could have on the protected Lough Oughter, as well as on Upper and Lower Lough Erne.

An Taisce and other groups raised the issue of Aughaweenagh Fartrin bog, which is northeast of the site and could be damaged if the quarry, itself proposed on peatland, was allowed to go ahead.

While the planning application was withdrawn, resubmitted and then withdrawn again, locals are concerned Mannok will “probably pursue it again”.

“There's always ongoing debate here among the locals,” Mr Gilroy said. “‘Have they given up on the planning application or have they not?’”

In the meantime, volunteers have been working to restore the bog, having won funding from the local Credit Union.

Mr Gilroy added: “Leader [an EU funding programme] are very keen to give us funding for this project, so it would make no sense for Cavan County Council to grant the application for a quarry immediately adjacent to it.”

Mannok did not respond to requests for a comment. A council spokesperson said: “It is not appropriate for Cavan County Council to comment on individual cases.”

Article title: Smog in Shymkent: Akim Syzdykbekov explains the source of the dirty air
Full article text: What happened? Shymkent Mayor Gabit Syzdykbekov commented on the widespread complaints from residents about deteriorating air quality at a press conference at the Central Communications Service. He stated that there is no health threat, but confirmed that pollution issues are indeed being reported. Details Journalists have noted that residents' complaints continue unabated: people write about the persistent smell of burning and gas, and post photos on social media of themselves walking around the city wearing respirators—otherwise, breathing is simply difficult. "Meanwhile, local environmentalists insist there are no exceedances in the city. But if you look at international data, specifically Climate Trace, the Shymkent Oil Refinery, Shymkentcement, and Standard Cement are among the companies that emit more particulate matter than over 90% of industrial facilities worldwide. Why do the figures from government environmental agencies differ so widely?" the journalist asked. Gabit Syzdykbekov acknowledged that there are periods in the city when air quality "leaves much to be desired." He attributed this to several factors, primarily the operation of industrial enterprises. "We conduct regular inspections and negotiate with businesses to ensure they use the most modern air purification filters. Secondly, the heating season has an impact. Many residents don't use gas. Even heating a sauna affects air quality. Windless weather also has an impact, especially during the heating season," the mayor explained. Checks and security Gabit Syzdykbekov noted that the Akimat conducts regular inspections and is in constant contact with environmental activists. Environmentalists conduct inspections of businesses and other facilities. "Based on the results of 10 months, if I'm not mistaken, there have already been about 30 inspections. Fines have been imposed somewhere around 40 million. The work is ongoing," the akim reported. When asked why data from local environmental services differs from international ones, Gabit Syzdykbekov responded that he trusts local environmentalists more, as he doesn't know whether international experts actually come to Shymkent to test air quality. "Our city is relatively safe, but I repeat: the primary influence is the heating season and industry, which we fine and force to constantly use special filters," the mayor noted. Context At the end of November, residents of Shymkent complained en masse about deteriorating air quality, with smog and severe air pollution present throughout the city. BES.media sent a request to the Akimat to determine the causes of the pollution and the measures planned. A response was received from the Shymkent Department of Ecology, part of the Committee for Environmental Regulation and Control of the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources. The department confirmed that elevated air pollution levels were recorded in the city from November 18 to 26. The department clarified that air quality in Shymkent is monitored at seven permanent stations. At four of them (PNZ Nos. 1, 2, 3, and 8), samples are collected manually, while at three more (PNZ Nos. 5, 6, and the station in Kyzylsay), data is collected automatically. According to daily air quality reports, hydrogen sulfide levels exceeded the permissible limits in November. The department's testing laboratory also detected elevated concentrations of carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and sulfur dioxide, but they remain within acceptable limits. WAS ANYONE PUNISHED? The Department of Ecology reported that 29 scheduled and unscheduled inspections were conducted in the first 10 months of 2025. As a result, 50 administrative cases were initiated, and fines imposed totaled approximately 37.6 million tenge, of which 32.6 million tenge were recovered. Nineteen natural resource users were inspected in Shymkent's industrial zones. By court order, the operations of five companies were temporarily suspended: Hill LLC, Hermes BE LLC, Kategoriya DM LLC, Khabibulla Individual Entrepreneur, and Muhammad Individual Entrepreneur. WHERE TO MONITOR THE AIR CONDITIONS To know how safe the air is to breathe, citizens must have constant access to air quality data. Therefore, journalists asked for clarification on where such data is published. The department reported that the Ministry of Ecology has developed an automated information system for collecting, organizing, storing, processing, and disseminating environmental information. Citizens can monitor this information on the website . In addition, information on the results of measurements conducted by the department is regularly published on the department's electronic digital information pages on Facebook and Instagram. Environmental monitoring data is also available on the Kazhydromet website . Furthermore, the Air.kz mobile app provides real-time information on Shymkent's pollution by displaying actual pollutant concentrations from observation posts located throughout the city, the department said. WHAT'S LIKE IN OTHER CITIES In Atyrau, the World Health Organization (WHO), in collaboration with local authorities, will conduct a study of the environmental situation and its impact on the health of residents in the region. The results of the analysis will determine whether local residents will receive compensation and benefits. Residents of Astana faced the effects of heavy smog on December 2: according to environmentalists, air quality in the capital deteriorated sharply and exceeded acceptable levels. At 6 a.m., the AQI (Air Quality Index) reached 131, a critical pollution level. Furthermore, a study by the Almaty Air Initiative found that one in four Almaty residents is already considering moving, and 80% report deteriorating health due to smog. Shymkent residents also actively complained about air quality on social media. WHAT ELSE BES.media previously published a special project, "No Right to Clean Air: What Almaty Residents Breathe and How to Eliminate Smog in the City." Why has Kazakhstan's largest city been unable to escape its ecological trap for over a decade? How is it that, despite gasification and close attention to the problem, air quality in Almaty continues to deteriorate? This not only causes allergies, asthma, and other illnesses, but also impacts fetal development. Where does smog come from, how dangerous is it, what consequences can it have, and can anything be done about it? Why is this important? Air quality directly impacts human health. The WHO notes that air pollution in both urban and rural areas leads to the formation of fine particulate matter, which is associated with strokes, heart disease, lung cancer, and acute and chronic respiratory diseases. In many regions and cities across the region, Kazakhstanis complain about polluted air. Therefore, to address this problem, authorities must work to hold accountable those who cause harm to the people.

Article title: Experts and authorities commented on Almaty residents' complaints about poor air quality and dirty rain.
Full article text: By the end of 2025, Almaty once again found itself among the most polluted cities in the world: according to IQAir, the city regularly ranks among the top for PM2.5 levels, and in January, the pollution index reached 256 points—the "very unhealthy" category. The situation only worsened in the fall and winter: according to a study by the Almaty Air Initiative, the proportion of those dissatisfied with air quality increased from 42% in 2024 to 50% in 2025, and 63% of residents directly say smog bothers them. Against this backdrop, December in Almaty is marked by dense haze, dark rain, and widespread complaints from residents. SHYNDYK.KZ investigated the reasons for this and what the authorities and environmentalists are saying. Bad air Over the past three years, air pollution in Almaty has ceased to be a "winter anomaly" and has become a constant. According to the Almaty Air Initiative, in 2024, the average annual PM2.5 concentration was approximately 20–21 μg/m³, approximately four times higher than the WHO recommendation (5 μg/m³). This year, the metropolis remains the most polluted major city in Kazakhstan and is among the 25 most polluted cities in the world, according to international rankings. According to a new AAI study, 50% of city residents consider the air quality in the city to be poor, 63% say smog bothers them very much or very much, and every second Almaty resident has at least once considered moving abroad for the winter due to air quality. Geography and climate only exacerbate the effect: the city is located in a basin at the foot of the mountains, and temperature inversions are common in winter, trapping cold air in the air. On windless days, smog literally hangs over Almaty, turning it into a gray roof. This morning, the Regional Communications Service reported that air quality in Almaty has noticeably improved: after rain and snow, the sky over the city has cleared, and the mountains are much more visible. Precipitation and wind have cleared the atmosphere, reducing smog levels. Kazhydromet is predicting snowfall and frost, which should further reduce pollutant concentrations. According to estimates, intense precipitation can reduce PM2.5 levels by up to 80% in just a few hours. Dynamics of deterioration By 2025, Almaty had repeatedly topped global air pollution rankings. On January 14, 2025, the AQI+ index reached 256, ranking it "very unhealthy." In the fall of 2025, IQAir recorded average PM2.5 concentrations in the city at approximately four times the WHO annual benchmark. December only continued this trend. According to the AQICN station at the US Embassy, ​​air quality was classified as "unhealthy" during some nighttime hours at the beginning of the month. And according to IQAir, during the day on December 9, the AQI in Almaty was "moderate," but PM2.5 concentrations remained approximately 4-5 times higher than WHO recommendations. Dirty rain One of the main topics of December was the phenomenon of "dirty rain." Residents noticed that precipitation left dark stains and streaks on light-colored clothing and cars. This photo was posted on social media by user Ainur Argancheeva. A video model published by Climate Trace provides additional context, showing how pollution from Almaty's thermal power plants moves throughout the city over the course of a day. Smog from the plants spreads across residential areas, confirming what residents have long seen with the naked eye. On December 1, Almaty's local authorities introduced new environmental regulations to reduce air pollution and upgrade the vehicle fleet. Separate regulations for air quality protection are being developed and are currently undergoing approval. At the same time, oversight of cafes and kebab houses using solid fuels has been strengthened: 12 establishments were inspected in the first days of December, with violations found at 10 of them. Fireworks display cancelled Amid persistent smog, Almaty residents are increasingly calling on social media to avoid setting off fireworks on New Year's. Users are posting images of dense, foggy pollution, complaining of poor health and a sharp reduction in visibility on the roads. Residents fear that fireworks displays on New Year's Eve could further increase the burden on already polluted air. Furthermore, users are reminded of the risks to people and animals: fireworks annually cause injuries, and emergency services are on high alert during the holidays. Videos are appearing online where people describe how smog aggravates their colds and flu, as well as shortness of breath and coughing. Some videos and stories show the city literally engulfed in a gray haze on windless evenings. A common theme in the comments is: "Every breath feels like a cigarette." This is how a new urban reality is taking shape: people aren't just complaining, but demanding concrete action from authorities and businesses. What the Ministry of Ecology says Amid complaints from residents about dark stains after rain, the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources of the Republic of Kazakhstan has officially clarified the cause of this phenomenon. "In recent weeks, Almaty has experienced a prolonged lack of precipitation, resulting in increased levels of pollutants—dust, soot, and emissions from vehicles and industrial plants—accumulating in the atmosphere. The situation was exacerbated by calm weather and a temperature inversion, which contributed to the accumulation of pollutants in the ground-level atmosphere," the department explained. The ministry emphasized that the first rain after a prolonged dry period acted as a natural air purifier. "Yesterday's rain was the first after a prolonged dry period and, as the so-called 'first cleansing rain,' washed a significant amount of these particles from the air. During precipitation, raindrops capture dust and soot in the atmosphere and transfer them to the ground. Therefore, dark marks may be visible on light-colored clothing, windows, or car bodies—this is a normal physical phenomenon," the Ministry of Ecology said in its official response. This phenomenon is known scientifically as "dirty rain" or "sooty rain." It doesn't mean the rain is toxic, but it does indicate a high concentration of pollutants in the air, particularly fine particles PM2.5 and PM10. The agency clarified that the rain itself is not hazardous. "Rain does wash pollutants out of the atmosphere—this is a scientifically proven process called 'wet deposition.' Dark spots form due to settled particles of dust, soot, and vehicle emissions caught in raindrops. If the rain were chemically hazardous or acidic, characteristic signs would be observed—odor, metal corrosion, scorched leaves, etc. In this case, none of this was observed," the Ministry of Ecology noted. The ministry's final explanation for the stains is clear: "The appearance of dark stains on clothing is the result of accumulated dust and soot particles being washed out of the atmosphere by the first rain." The agency emphasizes that "this is a natural phenomenon, but it serves as an indicator of elevated air pollution levels in Almaty." Main sources of pollution It's no coincidence that Almaty has once again been blanketed in smog. Experts believe there are several reasons for this. As is well known, the city itself is located in a basin at the foot of the Trans-Ili Alatau, and temperature inversions are common—when cold air "covers" warm air, preventing pollution from rising. And when the wind is calm and there's no precipitation, harmful substances accumulate in the ground layer, forming persistent smog. In the winter of 2025, these conditions were almost ideal for smog: the heating season, light winds, temperature fluctuations, and rare precipitation. Environmentalists have been repeating for years that Almaty's smog has several key sources: the thermal power plant, the flow of vehicles, and private and small-scale heating using coal and wood. According to ecologist Abay Erekenov, the key source of persistent smog in Almaty remains the thermal power industry, primarily coal-fired power plants. He emphasized that even with filters, emissions from the plants are literally "locked" over the city during winter inversions and are greatly amplified by light winds and the terrain. Environmentalist Azamatkhan Amirtayev , chairman of the green political party "Baytak," previously explained that Almaty's problem isn't limited to the burning of coal and solid fuels in the private sector and at energy facilities; vehicle exhaust contributes the lion's share to air quality. But it's the energy and heating industries that create constant "background" emissions, which are then compounded by vehicle exhaust, industrial sources, and smoke from cafes and private boilers. As a result, the city is effectively blanketed in polluted air in winter, and without systematic modernization of thermal power plants, a transition to cleaner technologies, and a review of the entire heating infrastructure, the smog problem, experts say, cannot be solved. Advice to residents While the city and government are seeking systemic solutions, residents are forced to protect themselves. For example, they should monitor real-time air quality measurements using apps like IQAir and AQICN. These apps display current AQI values ​​and concentrations of PM2.5, NO₂, and other pollutants in Almaty and its suburbs. The website AirKaz.org offers an online pollution map by station across the city. On polluted days, if possible, limit long walks and outdoor exercise, wear FFP2/N95 masks, and use air purifiers or at least wet cleaning. It's worth noting that city residents themselves can influence sources of air pollution. Some can give up old cars and unnecessary trips, using public transportation instead. The private sector, where possible, can switch to cleaner fuels and upgrade stoves and chimneys. And avoid fireworks displays on New Year's. Overall, city residents have been voting with concern for a long time. Today's smog in Almaty is no longer a seasonal problem—it's become part of the city's reality. December demonstrated once again that a single rainstorm can clear the air for only hours or days, but doesn't address the underlying cause. Without modernization of the energy sector, a transition to clean fuels, genuine transport reform, and strict environmental controls, the city will return to the same question every year: what are we breathing? Residents are expecting systemic solutions from the authorities, because the health and future of the city are at stake.

Article title: An environmental activist showed how smog from a thermal power plant disperses across Almaty.
Full article text: What happened? Climate Trace has published a video model showing how pollution from Almaty's thermal power plants moves around the city over the course of a day, said Ravkat Mukhtarov, project manager for the Almaty Air Initiative. Details "The Climate Trace study modeled the dispersion of PM2.5 emissions from point sources for 2023. In Almaty, the major sources are Thermal Power Plants No. 1, No. 2, and No. 3. The video shows how pollution spreads on days of high pollution, when there is no wind," wrote Ravkat Mukhtarov, project manager for the Almaty Air Initiative, on his Telegram channel. He added that “the more orange circles there are, the higher the pollution in the ground layer where we breathe.” Reference PM – particulate matter – solid suspended particles or fine dust. PM2.5 – particles up to 2.5 micrometers in diameter, which easily penetrate deep into the lungs and are considered particularly harmful to health. what was before In October of this year, the Almaty Akimat developed an air quality project with the goal of systematically reducing pollution levels in the metropolis. However, city authorities did not include the thermal power plant (TPP) on the list of major air polluters. According to Renaissance Plus, up to 60% of all emissions in the city come from motor vehicles. The remainder comes from private residential activity and stationary sources of pollution, such as industrial plants, saunas, barbecue joints, catering facilities, and construction. Research results In August of this year, the Central Asia Climate Foundation reported that Almaty's air quality has remained severely polluted for nine of the past 10 years. Only in 2017 were pollution levels slightly lower. As a result, more than 2.3 million city residents regularly breathe air containing harmful substances that exceed safe limits. According to the foundation, the city's geographic location was initially unfavorable for natural air exchange, and widespread, haphazard development over the past 20 years has worsened the situation to the point that the city is shrouded in a thick blanket of smog for more than six months. Context BES.media previously conducted a thorough study of this issue, the results of which were published in a special project. The article raises the question of why Almaty, Kazakhstan's largest city, has remained in an ecological trap for over a decade. Almaty residents complain of headaches, allergies, and constant colds—all because of the air they breathe. Almaty consistently tops the list of the most polluted cities in Kazakhstan. Many Astana residents also suffer from allergies: 28% of adults in Astana suffer from allergic rhinitis, and 20% of children have inflammatory skin diseases. Over the past three years, the number of adults suffering from bronchial asthma in the city has increased by 37%.
