Article title: Almaty's Coal Footprint: How Thermal Power Plant 2 Turned the City into a Global Smog Center
Full article text: According to the Climate Trace platform, one of Almaty's combined heat and power plants, CHPP-2, is among the top 10 global stationary sources of PM₂.₅ emissions—fine suspended particulate matter, hazardous to health, which Almaty residents inhale daily. This is a worrying sign: the city, which has struggled with smog and air pollution for years, is once again at the forefront of environmental concerns. A Baq.kz correspondent explored the reasons, experts' opinions, and how the authorities plan to improve the situation. Why was CHPP-2 blacklisted? Experts from the Almaty Air Initiative Foundation have concluded that CHPP-2 is among the world's largest sources of PM₂.₅ emissions. In 2024, tens of tons of these particles were recorded from the CHPP: approximately 94 tons of these microparticles in that year alone. The problem is that CHPP-2 and CHPP-3 use high-ash coal, which exacerbates the problem: the combustion process produces large quantities of fine dust and toxic compounds. According to IQAir, Almaty ranks second among cities in the world for air pollution (as of certain dates), with a high AQI and exceedances of maximum allowable levels. The coal used at combined heat and power plants (CHPs) contains many impurities and high ash content. Combustion produces extremely fine particles that are difficult to filter. Furthermore, many cleaning, filtration, and ash and dust collection systems are technically outdated or ineffective. CHPs lack state-of-the-art filters, electrostatic precipitators, and gas scrubbing systems. "We've been warning for a long time: unless the treatment systems at the combined heat and power plant are upgraded, the problem won't go away. Being included in global rankings is a wake-up call. We need a plan to upgrade the combined heat and power plant, convert it to gas-fired cogeneration, and completely phase out coal. Ekibastuz coal is a major polluter," says environmentalist and public figure Abai Erekenov. The graph shows that PM₂.₅ levels increase during the winter season, peaking in 2024–2025. Interestingly, the main contributors to the city's pollution are TPP-2, which accounts for about 40%, private homes that burn coal and wood also contribute 30%, transport 20%, and industrial facilities 10%. In terms of air emissions, Almaty's Thermal Power Plant-2 is second only to the largest coal-fired power plants in India and China. However, when comparing this single Kazakh city with densely populated megacities around the world, it becomes clear that effective air pollution control measures have not been implemented in Almaty. There are several other reasons why Almaty's air pollution is becoming more severe. First, the city's location in a mountain basin creates conditions for stagnant air: in winter, the air is cold, there's no wind, and temperature inversions trap pollution in the lower layers of the atmosphere. Second, until recently, there were insufficient measuring stations and automated posts. Furthermore, the system for notifying the public about deteriorating air quality was weak. How the authorities are dealing with the problem Last year, the city's Department of Ecology allocated 10 billion 771 million tenge for environmental improvements. These figures provide insight: CHPP-2 is not just a local polluter, but a globally significant source of emissions that impacts not only Almaty but also the regional environment. Expenditures on environmental programs increased from 3.1 billion tenge in 2018 to 10.7 billion tenge in 2024. At the thermal power plant, technology has begun to be updated: the Akimat has installed eight stationary and two mobile automated air monitoring stations. The city plans to upgrade its filtration systems, including electrostatic precipitators, wet and dry cleaning systems, desulfurization, and ash separation. It will gradually transition to less polluting fuels—gas or cleaner coal, where possible. Authorities have also launched a project to inform the public about air quality via LED screens. In Almaty, work is underway on all three sources of city pollution: the Combined Heat and Power Plant (CHP-2), the State District Power Plant (GRES), coal-fired boiler houses, and the foundry. Plans include reducing emissions, implementing "green transport" by increasing the number of electric and gas-powered buses, updating the public transport fleet, building new public transport lines, and restricting the entry of older vehicles without catalytic converters (LEZs) into Low Emission Zones (LEZs). In addition, so-called "green belts" and "green islands" will be created around the CHPP to prevent dust from spreading. Plants that accumulate metals, such as chestnut, juniper, and others, will be planted there. As for the private sector, the use of coal will be reduced, and stoves will be gradually replaced by gas, electricity, and central heating in areas where this is possible. The new microdistricts will be built taking into account the mountain-valley wind corridors of air circulation in order to minimize obstacles to air movement. Expert opinions and ways out of the crisis According to experts, the mistake in urban development policy is that authorities are returning to solutions that were proposed by experts 10–15 years ago. Ecologist Abai Erekenov points out that the idea of ​​modernizing Almaty's energy system is nothing new—the city has had existing design solutions for many years that would allow for a gradual phase-out of coal-fired capacity. He notes that even during the development of the city's master plan, the gradual replacement of outdated heat sources with modern cogeneration units—compact plants that simultaneously produce heat, hot water, and electricity with very high efficiency—was discussed. "The latest General Plan proposed creating cogeneration units on the sites of all these boiler houses, combined heat and power plants, and power plants—something the authorities are currently doing only at CHPP-2, albeit on a smaller scale. Converting the CHPP to gas would free up land where coal and gold mines were stored. There are over a hundred such facilities throughout the city. They were included in the original version of the General Plan, and the idea was actually proposed by the document's designers themselves, but was later abandoned," says Erekenov. He explains that geothermal heating systems are heat pumps based on the principles of air conditioners and refrigerators, and details their efficiency and advantages over traditional boilers. "A heat pump is an inverter air conditioner that captures heat from inside and expels it outside. In winter, it conversely draws heat from outside and pumps it into the home. These systems can have an efficiency ratio of up to 5:1—meaning they produce 5 kilowatts of heat for every kilowatt of electricity. This has long been common in Europe and the US," explains the ecologist. According to him, combined solutions could be implemented in Almaty: geothermal heating and solar power stations for shopping centers, office buildings, and large residential complexes. This would reduce the load on the city's energy system and completely eliminate emissions. However, according to him, key points of this program were excluded from the final version of the General Plan without the participation of experts and the public. The ecologist emphasizes that modernization should not be limited to just CHPP-2. "Everything has been pinned down to CHPP-2, but we have hundreds of boiler houses. They're all listed in the city's General Plan. To clean the air, we need to gasify everything—not just burn gas like a kettle, but install cogeneration units. They're compact and energy-efficient—they produce more heat and electricity per thousand cubic meters of gas than conventional boiler houses. Tariffs will be lower, the air will be cleaner, and people won't complain. Moreover, all this can be accomplished in two to three years," the expert notes. The ecologist emphasizes that international partners are ready to assist Kazakhstan financially and technologically. The EBRD and European manufacturers are willing to finance heat pumps and cogeneration systems with low-interest loans, but the Akimat is not taking advantage of these opportunities. "The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which is financing cogeneration at CHPP-2, is ready to provide loans to private businesses and even individuals. The funds have been allocated, so I don't even have to look for them. If I own an office and want to switch to a heat pump or cogeneration, I can get a preferential loan. They are also ready to finance private homes. If I install a heat pump, I disconnect from the city grid, reducing the load on the city. And European manufacturers—Italians, Germans—are ready to provide export-import loans for the supply of equipment," the expert says. Other sources of pollution in the city Experts agree with the authorities: the combined heat and power plant remains the most visible "tip of the iceberg," but there are other polluters as well. They believe these include not only thousands of private homes burning coal and wood, old cars, but also industry. Abai Erekenov provides a detailed classification of the main sources of air pollution in Almaty, based on their contribution levels. According to him, the main polluters are thermal power plants, district heating plants, and coal-fired boilers, followed by industry, including foundries within the city limits. "They need to be moved outside the city limits, at least towards Kunayev. Next in line is Almaty International Airport. One Boeing aircraft burns as much kerosene per year as two hundred thousand cars. And yet, the airport plans to increase the number of aircraft departures by 200,000 per year. According to the General Plan, Almaty International Airport was supposed to be moved towards Kapchagay, but that idea was later abandoned because it would be too expensive for the Turks to build a new airport. Heavy transport is in fourth place – these are Chinese trucks and buses, which don't meet any environmental standards for emissions or noise. After a year of use, they fall apart and pollute the air around them. And yet, people continue to buy them. And in last place are old passenger cars. Modern Euro-4 or Euro-5 vehicles emit almost no pollutants if they use normal fuel," says the ecologist. The ecologist adds that the claims about "developing public transport" in the General Plan are not supported by actual research into Almaty's passenger traffic. He attributes the lack of infrastructure solutions to the same bureaucratic substitution mechanism: no research is available, and all genuine expert comments are ignored. "The authorities say, 'Switch to public transportation.' But why isn't there a public transportation system in the General Plan? If you want people to switch, build a metro. A public transportation system assumes that you can get from any point in the city using three modes of public transportation. We don't have that. And this isn't just our opinion; international experts who conducted research here say the same thing. Our developers haven't conducted any research on traffic and passenger flows," the ecologist says. He emphasizes that the Almaty authorities had unique data at their disposal that could have served as the basis for sound urban planning and environmental reform. However, the results of professional research conducted by American experts were never used. "The Akimat simply didn't use the research conducted by the Americans in Almaty over the course of two years. Even though these studies for 2016-2017 were given to the authorities for free. They included traffic flow and passenger flow. After all, they had professional equipment that counted not only cars and buses but also the number of passengers. They performed all the calculations," the ecologist notes. The inclusion of Almaty's Thermal Power Plant 2 among the world's top polluters is a wake-up call: the city is on the brink of an environmental crisis, and without serious measures—modernization, strict monitoring, and a transition to clean technologies—the situation will continue to worsen. If the mayor's office, environmentalists, and businesses find consensus, formulate a clear development plan, allocate funds, and implement it responsibly, Almaty could cease to be considered one of the "dirtiest cities."

Article title: Can switching to gas-fired CHP solve the problem of polluted air in Almaty? Experts analyze what causes thick smog in the metropolis
Full article text: The main sources of pollution in Almaty in winter are the coal-fired CHP-2 and CHP-3. According to international estimates, the actual emissions from these facilities may be much higher than the official figures. So it is not a myth that the residents of the metropolis inhale 70 cigarettes of smoke per month. Since when has the Thermal Power Plant in Almaty been operating on gas and will this change improve the air quality in the metropolis? In general, can the problem of thick smog in Almaty be solved? Stan.kz news agency checked with the Almaty akimat, as well as specialists from the fund fighting the problem of polluted air. Why is the conversion and modernization of CHP-2 to gas delayed? Let us recall that the issue of converting the thermal power plant in Almaty to gas was raised in 2020. The akimat said at the time that the plant would be modernized in 2025. Five years have passed, but the Almaty CHP-2 has not yet been converted to gas, and is still operating on coal. And eco-activists of the metropolis and experts concerned about the air problem name the thermal power plant as one of the factors polluting the air in Almaty. In this regard, the Stan.kz news agency sent a query to the Almaty akimat. Our query was answered by Almaty Power Stations JSC and the Department of Ecology and Environment. According to those responsible, the project "Modernization of Thermal Power Plant-2 with minimal impact on the environment" has been extended for 1 year. The project "Modernization of Almaty CHP-2 with minimal environmental impact" has been extended due to a significant change in the terms of delivery of the main equipment by SIEMENS ENERGY. That is, the completion date of the project has been extended by 1 year - until the end of 2026. In addition, on August 10, 2023, by order of the First Deputy Prime Minister R.V. Sklyar, a Roadmap with a responsibility matrix for the implementation of the project "Modernization of Almaty CHP-2" with minimal environmental impact was approved. According to the document, the term of the EPC contract is set at 39 months (June 2023 - September 2026)," the response provided to us states. The center will not be renovated for 39 months According to the akimat, the center will not be renovated for 39 months. However, the project is expected to be completed and put into operation by the end of 2026. It is expected that the deadline will not be extended, and the project is planned to be implemented on time. "When implementing the gasification project "Almaty CHP-2 modernization", efficient gas turbine units will be installed to reduce harmful emissions by 93%, from 37,100 tons to 2,700 tons, and this will be achieved through the use of natural gas. This meets the standards of the European Union and the requirements for the introduction of the best available technologies in Kazakhstan. Greenhouse gases (CO2) will be reduced by 38%, from 4,000 tons to 2,500 tons. In addition to reducing harmful emissions, no ash residue will be formed after gasification," the departments of the Almaty akimat assured. CHPP-2 is among the 10% of the world's largest polluters According to the Almaty Air Initiative, air quality in Almaty depends on many factors and varies throughout the four seasons and time of day. However, in winter, the main sources of pollution are the coal-fired CHPP-2 and CHPP-3. "Almaty is located in a lowland, so air circulation is poor. During a temperature inversion, the upper layer of warm air acts like a lid, trapping cold and polluted air close to the ground. As a result, emissions accumulate below, and the concentration of pollution increases sharply. In winter, the main sources of pollution are coal-fired CHPP-2 and CHPP-3. They operate on coal with an ash content of 42%, without modern filtration systems. According to international estimates, the actual emissions of these facilities may be much higher than official figures. It should be noted that, according to Climate Trace data, CHPP-2 is among the 10% of the largest polluters in the world," says Zhuldyz Saulebekova, director of the fund. What is the proportion of vehicle exhaust in polluted air? The contribution of traffic to air quality in a metropolis depends on the season, traffic flow, and weather. In addition, the formation of smog is also affected by the private sector and air coming from the region. "According to our observations, it is not advisable to assess the share of transport only by total emissions. It strongly depends on the season, traffic density and weather. During inversions and traffic jams, the share of transport emissions reaches 60–70% in terms of PM₂.₅ and NO₂ (nitrogen dioxide). And when there is good ventilation, it drops to 15–20%. In addition, in the cold season, the air is significantly polluted by the private sector. There, coal, fuel and waste are still used for heating. During adverse weather conditions, polluted air from the Almaty region is drawn towards the city, which further increases the level of smog and pollution," the specialist says. Which area has the dirtiest air? Experts have named the areas in the city with the dirtiest air and the relatively cleanest. "The worst situation is observed in the northern (lower) part of the city and along highways. The "plate effect" (inversion and weak air exchange at the foot of the mountains) retains pollution, and vehicles, especially near roads, increase the level of NO₂. Now the map clearly shows the "red" readings of sensors in densely built-up areas, in the private sector burning coal, near large sources such as baths, taverns and CHP. The southern districts (Medeu and Bostandyk districts) are relatively clean. Here the average annual concentration is two times lower than in the northeastern parts of the city," says Zhuldyz Saulebekova. How can we solve the problem of polluted air in Almaty? According to experts, improving air quality requires a comprehensive approach that includes technological and management solutions: Gasification and modernization of CHP plants, installation of effective filtration systems, and strict emission control. A private sector coal phase-out program and the gradual connection of homes to gas or central heating systems. And where this is not yet possible, at least switching to briquetted or low-sulfur fuels, which will significantly reduce emissions. Develop environmentally friendly and affordable public transport, introduce Low Emission Zones to limit the impact of older vehicles, and encourage the transition to electric vehicles. Making data transparent means automatically monitoring emissions and publicly publishing the results, closing legislative loopholes that allow polluters to evade responsibility. The level of air pollution in winter is equivalent to inhaling 70 cigarettes a month, this is not a myth The representative of the foundation shared the results of research in recent years. According to the data, in 2024, the level of air pollution was assessed as high. The amount of harmful substances in the air exceeded the permissible limit up to 30 times a day. "According to our data for 2024, the concentration of PM2.5 and nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) is 4-6 times higher than the World Health Organization's recommendations. From November to February, the pollution level is equivalent to inhaling 70 cigarettes per month. In winter, the concentration of PM2.5 is about 5 times higher than in summer, and NO₂ is 2 times higher. This excess is maintained throughout the year. According to Kazhydromet, in 2024, the level of air pollution was assessed as high: 11,024 exceedances of the limit were recorded for NO₂, that is, the amount of this harmful substance in the air exceeded the limit up to 30 times per day. In addition, ozone was recorded more than 1,000 times in excess of the limit, and the average daily levels of ozone and nitrogen oxides often exceeded the norm. The situation has not improved significantly compared to 2020, when Kazhydromet also assessed air pollution as high," he says. The main change is the openness of the data. Anyone can monitor the level of the cloud. Today, hundreds of sensors are installed in Almaty that measure pollution levels in real time. While the idea of ​​air pollution in a megacity used to seem abstract, now it is not only visible, but also clearly understood, says Zhuldyz Saulebekova. "The main change in recent years is data transparency. Thanks to the efforts of the Almaty Air Initiative and sponsors, hundreds of sensors have been installed in the city that measure pollution levels in real time. All data is open to everyone. The data can be viewed in the MyCar application and on the dashboard.air.org.kz dashboard launched this year. Here, each resident can see the indicators of their air and compare them by year, month, hour, and district. If earlier this problem seemed abstract, now it has become visible and measurable. The tools, data, and demand necessary for the city to move to systematic solutions have appeared. A mobile application is also being developed to make monitoring even more convenient and accessible," says the director of the Foundation for Combating Air Pollution. Almaty is currently ranked 4th in the world for air quality. The top three are Pakistan, India, and China. What should we do to improve the air quality in Almaty? The fund's specialists and eco-activists have named simple but systematic steps that everyone can take and start: Use your personal car as little as possible, take public transport, walk or use car sharing and cycling. Monitoring the condition of the car, a properly functioning engine and an installed catalytic converter can significantly reduce toxic emissions. Not removing the catalytic converter, timely passing technical inspections, and not using fuel of questionable quality. Avoid burning trash, leaves, tires, and debris. These are one of the main sources of dioxins and fine particles in the air. Avoid setting off fireworks and burning open fires. These pollute the air with heavy metals and fine particles. Energy efficiency at home - thermal insulation, modern heating devices, and responsible consumption of electricity - reduces the load on thermal power plants and the overall volume of emissions. Monitor air quality at dashboard.air.org.kz and take it into account in your planning. The most important thing is to talk about the problem and create a culture of environmental responsibility. When people become more aware of the connection between their actions and air quality, not only behavior changes, but also the city itself. What experience has been used abroad? Beijing was one of the most polluted cities in the world a decade ago, but in recent years it has managed to significantly reduce the concentration of harmful substances. To do this, old coal-fired power plants were closed, renovated, converted to gas, old car traffic was restricted, public transport was developed, and industrial emissions were strictly controlled. Beijing has a single digital monitoring system that combines data from thousands of ground stations, satellites, and meteorological services. The introduction of Low Emission Zones (LEZ) and Ultra Low Emission Zones (ULEZ) in European cities such as London and Berlin has shown promising results in reducing NO₂ levels by 20–60% and shifting vehicles to cleaner modes. Barcelona and Shenzhen are using smart traffic lights that control traffic in real time using artificial intelligence analysis. This reduces congestion and, therefore, the generation of polluted air. In Amsterdam, an artificial intelligence energy management system analyzes data from "smart" meters and weather forecasts to balance energy consumption and reduce costs.

Article title: Climate Trace: Almaty's CHPP-2 is among the top 10% of PM 2.5 superpollutants worldwide.
Full article text: The international Climate Trace coalition uses satellites and AI to track emission sources around the world, including in Kazakhstan. The Almaty Air Initiative Foundation analyzed their data for the country. "The analysis showed that one of the three major stationary sources of PM 2.5 emissions in Almaty is among the top 10% of polluters for this indicator among all monitored facilities globally. This is the Almaty Thermal Power Plant-2, and given its installed capacity and use of high-ash coal as its primary fuel, it was designated a 'super-polluter.' According to the study, the Almaty Thermal Power Plant-2 emitted 94 tons of PM 2.5 into the atmosphere in 2024," the foundation reported. The Climate Trace tool clearly shows the spread of PM 2.5 plumes—fine particles that are the most dangerous to human health. "The Climate Trace interactive map, based on satellite monitoring and AI, helps us more accurately understand the sources of pollution in Almaty and other cities in Kazakhstan. Yes, the country still relies on coal, and in an era of rapid technological advances and AI, energy consumption will only increase. But innovation and modernization must be key to reducing harm (to public health)," said Zhuldyz Saulebekova, Executive Director of the Almaty Air Initiative. For Almaty, emission scenario modelling results are available for both prevailing and worst-case meteorological conditions, demonstrating the scale of potential impacts on residential areas. What else is important? Since CHPP-2 and CHPP-3 use high-ash coal, they are considered among the main causes of high PM 2.5 concentrations in the city. Due to the burning of solid fuels in winter and unfavorable weather conditions, Almaty topped the IQair online ranking of cities with the most polluted air during certain hours last season. The Almaty Air Initiative Foundation supports the initiative to convert the city's combined heat and power plants (CHPs) to natural gas . The foundation believes this should reduce emissions from CHP-2 by 12 times , and from CHP-3 by approximately 8-9 times . "Furthermore, it is important to develop a systematic approach to managing such facilities – implementing modern filters, establishing automatic emission controls, publishing data, and maintaining an open dialogue with energy companies, as well as analyzing the impact on the population through independent monitoring and local data," added Air Initiative Almaty.

Article title: How much will the ecology improve if Almaty thermal power plants switch to gas?
Full article text:
Two thermal power plants in Almaty are to be fully converted to gas by December 31, 2026. However, the minister, who visited the construction sites, was not satisfied. Based on extensive research , a correspondent for the Caravan.kz media portal tried to find out when the transition to gas will be completed and the amount of money spent on it. Even the question of how much the ecology and air quality will improve after the transition is worrying society.

Energy Minister Yerlan Akkenzhenov visited the construction sites of CHPP-2 and CHPP-3 in Almaty. Dissatisfied with the pace of work on the second facility , he demanded that contractors accelerate the work. He also warned that video surveillance would be installed to monitor the construction progress, and that deadlines would not be missed.

It is worth noting that the CHP-2, which is being rebuilt , was promised to be converted to gas by 2025. Later, the deadline was moved to September 2026. Kassym-Jomart Tokayev also spoke about accelerating the pace of work in 2021. And the very first task was given by the then President Nursultan Nazarbayev in 2017. At that time, the deadline was set for 2020. It should be noted that the construction site is located near the current coal-fired station.

Almaty residents have high hopes that if CHP plants switch to gas, the city's air will be cleaner. However, the current reality is different. Almaty is consistently ranked in the top 10 in terms of air pollution . For example, in October last year, the city ranked fourth after Lahore, Karachi, and Delhi.

What is the stage of construction of CHP-3, which the minister criticized?

A week before the Minister of Energy visited the construction site, the Almaty City Department of Energy and Water Supply responded to a question from Shishkin_like and reported that the design and estimate documentation for CHP-3 was undergoing a comprehensive external state examination. According to the department, preparatory and preliminary work had been carried out at the construction site, most of the main equipment had been delivered, some was on the way, and some was at the production stage. It is worth noting that CHP-3 is not being built from scratch, it is only being modernized, that is, a gas station is being built.

How will the transition to gas be technically implemented after construction is completed?

Almaty city and region are provided with heat and electricity by Almaty Electric Power Plants JSC (“AlES”), a subsidiary of Samruk-Energo. The enterprise has a number of heat and power facilities, including CHP-2 and CHP-3. It is the owner, operator and user of these plants. In response to our inquiry, the company’s specialists explained that after the gas-fired thermal power plant at CHP-2 is launched, the existing coal-fired equipment will be phased out and conserved. The response received by the editorial office before the minister’s visit generally stated that commissioning and adjustment work is planned for 2026–2027. It is not yet known whether the minister’s visit will affect the change in deadlines. The AlES website indicates that the gas station at CHP-3 is scheduled to be commissioned in December 2026, and the coal station is scheduled to be dismantled in 2027.

In general, during the transition period, AlES is considering the possibility of using two types of fuel simultaneously. According to the operator, all measures to switch to gas are planned to avoid disruptions in heat supply during the heating season, including during peak loads.

What equipment will be installed?

CHPP-2 will be equipped with 4 water heaters and 3 steam boilers manufactured by the Chinese company Wuxi Huaguang Environment & Energy Group, as well as three waste heat boilers manufactured by the MHI Power Dongfang Boiler company. In addition, three gas turbine units manufactured by the German company Siemens Energy are planned. The generators are manufactured at one of Siemens' production sites in the USA. The main suppliers will provide service obligations for three years, after which maintenance and service will be carried out within the framework of the operating agreements between "AlES", contractors and equipment suppliers.

The design service life of CHP-2 is 30 years. Depending on the results of the subsequent technical analysis, the issue of major reconstruction, modernization or phased replacement of equipment will be resolved. As noted in the Energy Department, plans are usually developed for such facilities to extend their service life by major repairs and replacement of worn-out components. The installed electric capacity after switching to gas is 557 MW, thermal capacity is 957 Gcal/h.

CHPP-3 is also expected to operate for 30 years after modernization. The project plans to commission two combined cycle units. Today, the EPC contractor has signed contracts for the supply of key process equipment. In particular, gas turbines and generators from Ansaldo Energy (Italy), waste heat boilers from ZIO-Podolsk (Russia), and steam turbines and generators from Dongfang Electric International Corporation (China). The installed electrical capacity after switching to gas is up to 543.6 MW, and thermal capacity is up to 160 Gcal/h.

How much does it cost to convert CHP-2 to gas?

Within the framework of the project "Modernization of Almaty CHP-2 with reduced environmental impact", an EPC contract for the amount of 325.9 billion tenge was signed in May 2023 through the platform of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. This was reported by both the city's Energy and Water Supply Department and the Ministry of Energy. It is worth noting that the cost of the project on the website of the Development Bank of Kazakhstan is indicated as approximately 435.8 billion tenge . The bank may have updated this information due to changes in exchange rates.

Financing will be carried out at the expense of AlES's own funds and the authorized capital of Samruk-Energo JSC, as well as through loans from the EBRD, the Asian Development Bank and DBK. All credit lines provide for repayment within 15 years. However, AlES stated that the subject of financing is a commercial secret, and therefore this information cannot be disclosed. Bes.Media reported that in November 2022, AlES concluded loan agreements with the EBRD for 130 billion tenge (the bank's website indicates 126 billion tenge for 2022), in June 2023 with DBK for 117 billion tenge and with ADB for 98 billion tenge. According to DBK, the borrower's own share is approximately 87.2 billion tenge, and the loan cost is 0.73% per annum.

Construction work is being carried out by a consortium of Chinese corporations including Dongfang Electric International Corporation, PowerChina SEPCO1 Electric Power Construction, and PowerChina Hebei Electric Power Engineering.

Cost of reconstruction of CHPP-3 and contractors

According to the EPC contract, the project is estimated at more than 256.9 billion tenge . It is also being implemented at the expense of AlES' own funds and loans. Among the sources of financing are the Eurasian Development Bank, DBK and Halyk Bank. For financing, AlES issued bonds in the AIFC for 236.9 billion tenge . Of which, the EADB assumed the obligation to purchase bonds and concluded an agreement with AlES for 188 billion tenge.

How much will the performance of CHP-2 and CHP-3 improve?

Harmful substances

According to the Ministry of Energy, after switching to gas, it is expected that emissions of harmful substances from CHP-2 will decrease annually by 93% (from 37.1 thousand tons to 2.7 thousand tons, i.e. 14 times). For CHP-3, this figure will decrease by 88% - from 12.3 thousand tons to 1.5 thousand tons, i.e. 8 times. According to the Almaty Air Initiative, the transition of urban thermal power plants to gas will reduce emissions from CHP-2 by 12 times, and from CHP-3 by about 8–9 times. Recall that the concept of "emissions of harmful substances" includes a wide range of indicators, from fine particulate matter to heavy metals .

Greenhouse gas

According to the ministry, as a result of the operation of CHP-2, carbon dioxide (greenhouse gas) emissions will decrease by 38% (from 4 million tons to 2.5 million tons). For CHP-3, this figure will be 8% (from 1.5 million tons to 1.4 million tons). On average, the reduction for both stations will be 23%. This is in line with the forecasts published in the "KazNTZU Bulletin" for 2021 , which indicated that the volume of greenhouse gases will decrease by 20.4%.

Smog

Nitrogen oxides are considered one of the main causes of photochemical smog. A document authored by the AIFC states that the modernization of CHP-2 will reduce nitrogen oxide emissions by about 45%. And recently, at a meeting of the Presidential Council on the "transition to a green economy", it was announced that nitrogen oxide emissions will decrease by about 95%. Perhaps this is a combined indicator of two CHPs.

What pollutes the air: cars or CHP plants?

This question is hotly debated in society. Let's take a look at the opinions on this topic.

In 2018, Bauyrzhan Baibek, the mayor of Almaty, said that 70% of emissions were attributed to transport. Fact-checking conducted at the time showed that in December, the share of transport in terms of sulfur dioxide was 37%, and in terms of carbon monoxide (carbon monoxide) it was 62%.

During the same period, studies of the Almaty ecosystem conducted by the foresight agency EXIMAR showed that approximately 70% of pollutants emitted into the air were emitted by three CHP plants and coal-fired boilers.

Bakytzhan Sagintayev, the former mayor of Almaty, stated at one of the reporting meetings in 2021 that more than 60% of air pollution is caused by vehicles, about 30% by CHP-2, and the rest by industry, private homes, and other sources . Moreover, he spoke about this issue in the past tense, that is, he gave the impression that the problem had been solved during his time.

An article in the 2021 KazNTZU Bulletin states that transport is responsible for 33.2% of the total greenhouse gas emissions and 52% of pollutants. It is worth noting that the number of cars in the city is steadily growing, in May 2025 their number increased by more than 11% compared to the same period last year. This applies only to locally registered vehicles.

Of course, the conversion of CHP-2 and CHP-3 to gas will improve air quality. But it is not yet possible to say exactly how much it will be. Last year, 189 thousand tons of pollutants were recorded in the Almaty air basin. According to official statistics , 112 thousand tons or 60% of them are from transport, 52 thousand tons or 27.5% from industrial enterprises (including CHP-2 and CHP-3), and 21 thousand tons or 11% from the private sector.

There is an opinion that air pollution may persist even after CHPs switch to gas. According to Climate TRACE data (which monitors emissions using satellite data), CHP-1, which has been operating on gas since 2017, emitted more than 20 tons of particles into the atmosphere that could be hazardous to health in 2024. This is likely due to fuel oil used as a backup fuel .

Article title: 1.6 billion people breathe in fine dust emitted by fossil fuels... Seoul is also in the danger zone.
Full article text: It has been revealed that harmful substances emitted from the combustion of fossil fuels are threatening the health of at least 1.6 billion people. This is because ultrafine dust (PM2.5) emitted during the combustion of coal and oil has adverse health effects. According to an interactive map created by Climate Trace, a global greenhouse gas measurement organization, on the 24th (local time), fine dust and other air pollutants are entering the air near the homes of approximately 1.6 billion people. This interactive map, using satellite and sensor data, shows the flow of air pollutants into over 2,500 urban areas. The map is publicly accessible and accessible to anyone. According to the data, approximately 900 million of the world's 1.6 billion people live near high-emission industrial facilities, such as power plants, refineries, ports, and mines. The more pollutants a facility emits, the more pollutants it releases into the atmosphere. Seoul, South Korea, was included among the cities particularly severely affected by air pollutants. Ten other cities were also named, including New York, USA; Guangzhou, China; and Karachi, Pakistan. Climate Tracking said, "This map shows the direct link between the climate crisis and the serious threat air pollution poses to public health," and added, "Identifying which communities are most at risk is an urgent priority." Some in the United States see this data as a way to counter President Donald Trump's efforts to dismantle climate action. The Trump administration, which supports fossil fuels and denies climate change and renewable energy, has argued that it is willing to address pollution in any way it can. Ed Russo, Trump's environmental adviser, said at Climate Week in Rio de Janeiro in August that "we must combat pollution from dumps, landfills, and other sources," but did not specify how the Trump administration would address pollution. Environmental groups are concerned that the size of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), a key regulatory agency, will be reduced, making it less effective in addressing pollution. Al Gore, former U.S. Vice President and co-founder of Climate Trace, said there is a clear link between health and fossil fuels, noting that "air pollution from fossil fuel combustion facilities is carried by the wind to surrounding areas and causes 8.7 million deaths each year."

Article title: Seoul ranks third in the world in smoke pollution, following Karachi, Pakistan, and Guangzhou, China.
Full article text:
People will soon be able to use satellite technology and artificial intelligence (AI) to track dangerous soot pollution in their neighborhoods. This isn't much different from the way a nonprofit coalition led by former Vice President Al Gore plans to track approaching storms. Gore, which launched Climate Trace, which uses satellites to locate heat-trapping methane sources, expanded its system on the 24th to track sources and plumes of tiny particles called soot at the neighborhood level in 2,500 cities around the world. Particle pollution kills millions of people worldwide each year, and tens of thousands in the United States alone, according to research reports. Gore's coalition uses 300 satellites, 30,000 ground-based tracking sensors, and AI to track 137,095 particle pollution sources, 3,937 of which are classified as "mega-sources" based on their emissions. Gore hopes that within about a year, these trends will be available daily and could be integrated into weather apps, much like allergy reports. This system not only tracks pollutants, but also traces their sources.
 

 "Before AI, it was difficult for people to know exactly where air pollution was coming from," Gore said. "But when pollution is removed from homes and neighborhoods, and people are clearly aware of it, they will know the truth about their situation, and knowing the truth will be liberating."
 

 Unlike methane, soot pollution doesn't technically contribute to global warming, so it's not a climate issue. However, it is still caused by fossil fuel combustion. Gore said, "Nearly 9 million people die every year from greenhouse gas pollution and fine dust pollution, both of which are caused by burning fossil fuels." He said that if the 105-kilometer-long "Cancer Alley" between Baton Rouge and New Orleans, where the U.S. petrochemical industry is based, were considered a single country, it would have the fourth-highest per capita emissions of global warming pollutants in the world, after Turkmenistan, according to Climate Trace data analysis. Gore's Climate Trace added that Karachi, Pakistan, is most exposed to exhaust fumes, followed by Guangzhou, China, Seoul, New York, and Dhaka, Bangladesh.

Article title: Parties promise, NGOs propose measures for clean air, we all suffocate together every day
Full article text:
Large industrial capacities, illegal landfills, flooded catchment areas, non-functional measuring stations… are just some of the pollution factors that environmental organizations regularly warn about. The latest in the series is the reaction of Green Human City, which, citing Climate Trace, accused the Usje cement plant in Skopje of being one of the largest polluters in the world and is considered a super-emitter of PM 2.5 particles. " The City of Skopje and the Ministry of Environment (MOE) have been refusing for years to install measuring stations around the cement plant that would display 24-hour publicly available measurements, rather than accept illegal reports with gaps of 10 hours a day from a measuring station that the cement plant itself controls. Because the institutions are deaf and the inspections are in hibernation, citizens are self-organizing to blockade the cement plant on December 25 at 6 p.m. ," Green Human City announced. Because of this, Green Human City submitted the Initiative for the Dislocation of Usje to the City Council of Skopje, proposing that the Council " clearly take a position that heavy and highly polluting industry has no place in a densely populated area and that Usje must be dislocated outside of Skopje and outside of any populated area ." Pollution is a hot political topic In addition to being a health issue, pollution, especially in winter, is also becoming a hot political topic. SDSM has asked the Government to declare a state of ecological and health crisis. " We demand that a decision be made that establishes the reduction of air pollution as a priority, and that priority be given to the financing of measures by the City of Skopje, because so far no money has been invested in projects for cleaner air, the citizens are left to their own devices. Probably because of Prime Minister Mickoski's statements that the air in Skopje is cleaner than the air in Vienna. This must change immediately, the health of Skopje residents is at stake, half a million residents, children, adults, young people, everyone is affected, " said Katerina Canevska Arsovska , a councilor in the City Council of Skopje, at a press conference yesterday . She requested the convening of an extraordinary session and requested support from all council groups for the measures that SDSM will propose to the Council, which are free public transportation on days when the air is polluted, requesting money from the Government for free filters on the chimneys of major polluters, repurposing money for purifiers for citizens for ecological heating, enacting a ban on heating with wood and coal in areas with available central heating, clearing illegal landfills on the territory of the City of Skopje, washing the streets, and money for ecological projects. In December 2019, as part of the "Conversations for the Reconstruction of Macedonia" campaign, Mickoski, then from an opposition position, promised to reduce air pollution by 50 percent and a billion euros for gasification and environmental measures. A big public outcry also arose after the statement of the Mayor of Skopje, Orce Gjorgjievski, who said that he did not promise to perform miracles in the election campaign for the 2025 Local Elections. " I want to tell the citizens one thing very sincerely, and that is to have patience. I know, we have all been living this problem for years, we have been living it for decades. But I cannot and have not promised that I will perform miracles overnight, because that is impossible and irresponsible for a politician to say. But that I am acting, so that they can be convinced that Orce Gjorgjievski, nor the City of Skopje in the next four years, will never be put in a position to protect anyone, especially in conditions if someone is poisoning our people ," Gjorgjievski said last week in an appearance on TV 21. Parties copy each other's measures, but do not implement them The announcement by the City Council of Skopje that it will adopt a new comprehensive plan for environmental protection was met with a mixed reception. Marjan Kalevski , a councilor from Green Human City, says that all this time we have all been waiting for the development of some plans, and even those that have been adopted are not being implemented. " Many such documents proposed by the City of Skopje are copied from each other, every year with outdated information, without any weight to that document. All those documents are in a drawer, and no one is doing anything about it, nor is anyone working according to the guidelines of those plans. We have been submitting measures against air pollution to the City for years, and even those that were adopted by the majority have not been implemented. In addition, a lot of money is spent on the preparation of those plans. This plan will cost 75,000 euros ," Kalevski said in an interview with Telma. The 2024 election program "Macedonia is Yours," the program with which VMRO-DPMNE came to power, has a whole chapter and dozens of measures envisaged for environmental protection. From the establishment of an Environmental Fund, a Central Inspection Body and a Green Fund, through support for households for the purchase of new energy equipment, to the development of a Methodology for the Prevention of Pollution from Urban Communities and a Methodology for Solving the Problem of Air Pollution from Large Capacities Located Close to Urban Areas. The party also promised immediate protection of lakes and national parks, the installation of electric vehicle charging stations at every gas station, as well as the reforestation of Macedonia with 10 million seedlings per year. A year and a half later, neither reforestation has been carried out, nor are there pumps for electric vehicles at every gas station. Even fewer have the organs and bodies that VMRO-DPMNE promised been formed. As for the national parks, this party promised that Pelister, Galichica, Mavrovo and Shar Planina will receive systemic financial support to fulfill the basic goal of their operation - environmental protection. However, the non-governmental sector warned in June this year that for years the authorities have been doing nothing to have Mavrovo declared a national (NP) park again. " The law on the re-proclamation of Mavrovo National Park has not been adopted, the Mavrovo National Park Management Plan has not been adopted, numerous irregularities and illegal activities in the park have been reported, but have not been sanctioned. Approximately 80 percent of the funding of the Public Institution Mavrovo National Park comes from logging, an unsustainable practice contrary to the purpose of the protected area, and a decline in the populations of protected animal species in the park has also been observed ," the non-governmental sector reacted at the time. And the establishment of the Environmental Fund is also part of the 2016 election program "Plan for Life in Macedonia" with which SDSM came to power. In addition to the fund, this party promised an integrated system that would connect all three monitoring systems that track air, water and soil pollution, and the data would be publicly available to citizens. " The priority is the construction of wastewater treatment plants in all settlements with over 10,000 inhabitants, but also in smaller urban areas. We will make a map of contaminated soils in the country. We will complete the legislation on soil protection. We will develop a 'Cadastre of areas threatened by natural disasters in Macedonia with a degree of risk', which will define red zones (no construction allowed), yellow zones (construction is possible, but only with protective measures) and green zones (free for construction). We will regulate the catchment areas, clean the riverbeds and the canal system. Every year we will invest 10 million euros a year just for irrigation and drainage systems. We will establish a modern hydrometeorological system for early warning in case of storm risk ," SDSM promised at the time. Almost ten years later, villages and towns are still flooding, there is no cadastre of endangered areas, there are not even 10 million euros per year for irrigation and drainage systems, nor has a hydrometeorological system been established for early warning in case of storm risk. Last week, the Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning warned twice about extreme pollution in Kicevo, Strumica and Skopje . The National Development Strategy (NDS) 2024-2044, among other things, foresees the state to work intensively on green energy transformation. " The primary goal in this direction is to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve air quality and improve energy efficiency, thereby ensuring a healthier living environment for citizens. At the same time, the waste and wastewater management system needs to be renovated by increasing recycling rates and establishing standardized landfills, which will reduce our ecological footprint. The protection of nature and biodiversity is essential for improving the environment ," the NDS 2024-2044 states. To implement this plan, the National Development Strategy 2024-2044 envisages building a climate-neutral society with a low percentage of energy poverty and a healthy and clean environment. Article title: Green Human City Initiative for the Dislocation of Usje
Full article text: The independent coalition of eco-activists Green Human City has submitted an initiative to the Skopje City Council for the relocation of the Usje cement plant. We propose that the Council clearly take a position that heavy and highly polluting industry has no place in a densely populated area and that Usje must be relocated outside of Skopje and outside of any populated area, says a statement from Green Human City, a coalition that has one member in the Skopje City Council. "The initiative proposes that the Mayor of the City of Skopje submit this position to the Government, the Ministry of Environment and Spatial Planning, the State Environmental Inspectorate and the Parliament, so that they can further act within their competences. The Usje Cement Plant is a heavy and highly polluting industry installation (G1) that has been operating in the immediate vicinity of populated areas of Skopje for decades. Its location is a historical anachronism and directly contradicts the constitutionally guaranteed right of citizens to a healthy environment, as well as modern standards for the protection of public health. According to data from Climate Trace - one of the most relevant global sources for monitoring pollution - the Usje Cement Plant is among the 10% largest polluters in the world and is classified as a super emitter of PM2.5 particles. This further confirms the serious and long-term impact of this installation on air quality in Skopje. The inspection findings from 2023 showed serious systemic failures in institutional supervision. Reports have been accepted for emissions with gaps of 10 hours in 24 hours, contrary to the Regulation on Emission Measurement and from a monitoring station controlled by the cement plant itself. These findings resulted in a criminal complaint filed by the City of Skopje in January 2023. Despite this, neither a ban on operation, nor effective measures to drastically reduce pollution, nor the installation of independent measuring stations around Usje followed. Additionally, in September 2025, the Ministry of Environment proposed, and the Parliament adopted, a law by which, for the first time in the history of Macedonia, industrial pollution was classified as a "trade secret" - a law that was welcomed and positively assessed by Usje. This clearly indicates an institutional failure and abandonment of protecting the public interest. Skopje residents have been protesting against Usje's operations for years, and a civil blockade is scheduled again on December 25. "If the Inspectorate, the Ministry, the Parliament and the Prosecutor's Office do not act, the Skopje City Council - as the closest to the citizens and directly responsible for protecting their health - has both the right and the obligation to send a clear and strong political message. Every heavy and polluting industry must be relocated outside of Skopje, a city that has been among the most polluted in Europe for years and in which thousands of people, including children, die prematurely every year," Green Human City said.

Article title: These are the municipalities in Mexico that saw the greatest increase in pollution in 2025
Full article text:
The climate crisis in Mexico is not only measured at the national level, but is also clearly evident at the municipal level. Recent data from Climate TRACE shows that 11 municipalities in Mexico account for 50.1% of the main pollutants that cause global warming, driven by industrial, energy, and logistics activities. 

The urban areas of Mexico City, Monterrey, Guadalajara, Puebla and the port of Manzanillo concentrate 36.3% of the national inventory of carbon equivalent emissions (CO2e), making them the main sources of greenhouse gas (GHG) generation in the country. 

This high participation rate is due to the high population density, intense industrial and logistical activity, as well as the concentration of services, transportation, and energy consumption. In the case of the port of Manzanillo, its importance is explained by the volume of maritime and land trade, which increases emissions associated with the transport of goods and the use of fossil fuels. 

The emissions recorded in these areas include carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide, gases with a high global warming potential and a direct impact on accelerating climate change. 
Municipalities such as Ensenada in Baja California, Lázaro Cárdenas in Michoacán, and Silao in Guanajuato have seen increases in their carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emissions of 8.2%, 6.0%, and 4.2%, respectively. These areas are home to industrial ports, automotive manufacturing hubs, power plants, and logistics centers, all of which contribute to increased environmental pressure. 

In the case of Ensenada, port activity, maritime and land transport, as well as electricity generation and the export-related industry, account for a significant portion of the increase in emissions. Added to this is urban growth linked to commerce and tourism, which increases energy demand and vehicular traffic. The combination of these sources makes the municipality a critical emissions hotspot within the northwest of the country. 

Lázaro Cárdenas stands out for housing one of the most important industrial ports on the Mexican Pacific coast, with intensive steel production, large-scale cargo handling, and a constant flow of heavy transport. These activities, fundamental to foreign trade and national industry, depend heavily on energy-intensive processes, resulting in higher CO2e emissions and increasing environmental pressure on the region. 

Silao, for its part, has established itself as a hub of the Bajío automotive corridor, with assembly plants, auto parts suppliers, and logistics centers operating continuously. Vehicle manufacturing, the transportation of raw materials and finished products, and the electricity demand of the industrial parks explain the increase in its emissions. 
Conversely, some municipalities in the country significantly reduced their carbon equivalent emissions, reflecting progress in energy efficiency, changes in production methods, or reduced industrial activity. Tuxtepec, Oaxaca, led the reductions with a 7.14% decrease, followed by Monclova, Coahuila, with 6.85%, and Puebla, Puebla, with a 5.66% reduction. 

This trend was also seen in Agua Prieta, Sonora, where emissions fell by 5.01%, and Orizaba, Veracruz, with a 5% decrease. These results contrast with the increases observed in other industrial centers and show that these municipalities share similar local policies and improved urban management, according to information from their websites. 

The Government of Mexico, within its National Air Quality Strategy, mentions that municipalities, as part of the three levels of government, have a fundamental role in reducing polluting emissions, especially through shared and comprehensive air quality management and the reorientation of urban planning. 

The municipal contribution is based on integrating air quality into territorial and mobility planning and strengthening its operational and regulatory capacity to implement local management programs (ProAire) and monitor emission sources. The document states that this represents a shift so that addressing air quality is no longer the exclusive responsibility of environmental authorities.

In first place is the Nikola Tesla Thermal Power Plant (TENT) with 15.59 million tons, followed by Kostolac TE with 6.92 million and NIS 's oil and gas extraction with 5.37 million tons. The list also includes Železara Smederevo (1.96 million tons), TPP Kolubara, Novi Sad heating plant, TPP Morava , as well as the Tamnava and Radljevo mines . Among the top ten is the Pancevo Refinery with 0.81 million tons of CO2. One of the industries that currently consumes only oil derivatives is in 11th place: "Nikola Tesla" Airport , with 0.52 million tons, writes the Klima101 portal. Experts warn that thermal power plants are still the biggest source of emissions in Serbia, but that the steel and oil industries, which depend on the import of raw materials, are also a significant part of the problem. "When raw materials travel from South Africa, Brazil or China to reach Smederevo, it is clear that the issue of sustainability transcends national borders," said Dr. Mirko Nikolić from Södertörn University in Sweden. Article title: Top 10 largest CO2 emitters in Serbia: From thermal power plants, through oil and steel to landfills and airports
Full article text: The ten largest emitters in Serbia together produce over 31 million tons of carbon dioxide per year, which is over 60% of Serbia's total territorial emissions. The ten largest emitters in Serbia together produce over 31 million tons of carbon dioxide per year, which is over 60% of Serbia's total territorial emissions. This is what the Climate TRACE portal tells us , a non-profit coalition of organizations that uses data from over 300 satellites and sensors, and processes data with the help of artificial intelligence to obtain results from over 600 million sources of pollution around the world . The aim is to avoid the standard pain associated with reporting emissions of CO 2 and other harmful gases: traditional inventories rely on companies self-reporting their emissions (or not reporting them at all). The data is rounded up on a monthly basis and gives an almost "live" picture. In the text, we look primarily at the calculations for the year 2024. As the satellite data tell us, quite expectedly, thermal power plants are at the top of the list of the largest emitters in Serbia . The Nikola Tesla thermal power plant (TENT) is unparalleled, with its 15.59 million tons of CO 2 in 2024, followed by the Kostolac thermal power plant with 6.92 million, the Kolubara thermal power plant with 1.04, then the Novi Sad thermal power plant with 0.66 and the Morava thermal power plant with 0.61 million tons of CO 2 . For the sake of comparison, according to Climate TRACE, last year Serbia emitted a total of just over 60 million tons of greenhouse gases (which includes CO 2 and other gases) - thermal power plants were almost half of that total figure , Dr. Mirko Nikolić from Sodertorn University in Sweden writes for Klima101. Not only the burning, but also the mining of coal causes extensive emissions: within the EPS, the Tamnava and Radljevo mines are on the list of the 10 largest emitters (with 0.74 and 0.58 million tons of greenhouse gases, respectively). These figures are not so far from the data provided by the official state inventories, and they confirm that coal is an absolutely central problem for climate action in Serbia. However, coal is not the only problem – nor is the emissions picture as simple as it might seem. Roads of steel: from South Africa, via Smederevo to the European Union The fourth largest emitter in Serbia is Železara Smederevo, with 1.96 million tons of CO 2 . This is less than the world average, where the steel industry accounts for 7-8% of total energy emissions. But here it would be good to do a short analysis, because there are also wider emissions related to the work of the Ironworks . Namely, Climate TRACE estimates emissions at the point of production , but this excludes key elements of steel processing, such as energy and raw materials. The company HBIS, the owner of the Smederevo Ironworks, is the fifth largest steel producer on the planet, and the Smederevo Ironworks is part of global supply chains, as well as greenhouse gas emissions. To begin with, it should be taken into account that all the ore used by Železara, as well as coke, is imported (a high-energy type of coal used in furnaces for melting steel). Železara also uses natural gas as an energy source, of which, as is known, about 90% is also imported. Until the beginning of the war in Ukraine, most of the ore and coke came from Russia and Ukraine, but since then there have been alternative supply channels, including: South Africa, Australia, Brazil , India and China . Bearing in mind that, in principle, the exact sources of supply and transport routes of materials are impossible to calculate more precisely the emissions they cause. Certainly, the very fact that some of these raw materials go around the entire planet to reach Smederevo raises the question of sustainability. Given the sources of the ore, this transport certainly takes place mostly by ships, which are a notorious hole in emissions reporting and do not "belong" to any country. And the path of raw materials and products does not stop there. About half of the Železara's production is exported, mainly to European Union markets, so if we look not at territorial emissions, but at country emissions by consumption, it could be said that half of the Železara's emissions are exported. However, the matter is not so simple, because it is certain that a part of the emissions may still travel through the final products. We should keep in mind that Serbia actually imports more steel products than it exports in terms of economic value . At the global level, the steel industry is seen as a challenge for decarbonization, and although intensive work is being done to switch to electricity and furnaces that use hydrogen, the International Energy Agency (IEA) estimates that the steel industry is " not on track " to reach the so-called. net zero emissions by 2050. The mother company Železara "Smederevo" itself allegedly already makes "green steel" using hydrogen in its facilities in China, with significantly lower greenhouse gas emissions, but unfortunately, as far as is known, there are no plans to install such technologies in Serbia . Oil: Upstream and downstream of the refinery Somewhat similar problems of wider emission flows are also opened up by the operations of the Serbian Oil Industry, from the very extraction of oil and gas, as well as their processing. The largest item related to NIS is the extraction of oil and gas in Vojvodina, which Climate TRACE estimates at 5.37 million tons, which places this activity in 3rd place in the country in 2024. According to the portal's methodology, only emissions caused during production and transportation are included here. Processing is counted as a separate activity, as Climate TRACE counts emissions at the facility level or geographically localized activities. The portal estimates that the Pancevo Refinery produces 0.81 million tons of greenhouse gases . To this should be added HIP-Petrohemija with 0.23 million tons. These numbers refer only to the processes that take place within the scope of production, ie. refining. For fossil companies, "indirect" emissions are key, which are both "upstream" ( upstream ) and "downstream" ( downstream ) of the Refinery. Most of the raw materials that NIS processes are imported, and most of the emissions are produced by burning finished products. In 2024, NIS processed over 3.6 million tons of oil derivatives , and sold over 3.7 million tons, and is by far the largest supplier of motor fuels on the market. In accordance with this, it should be remembered that the oil and gas industry is one of the key points for Serbia's climate policy, primarily in transport. One of the industries that currently consumes only petroleum products is in 11th place on the list (9th in 2023): "Nikola Tesla" Airport, with 0.52 million tons. It is known that the aviation industry's emissions are not covered by the Paris Agreement, although they are among the largest by individual sector, representing at least 2% of world emissions and even up to 4% of total warming, taking condensation effects into account. Formally speaking, currently these emissions are the sole responsibility of the companies themselves to reduce emissions and should be solved by the market, and progress in this matter is very slow. Of course, it should be borne in mind that the policies of construction, maintenance and expansion of airports are often actually political decisions, and the entire infrastructure depends on them. Therefore, the quantification of emissions related to individual airports opens up the possibility of political action in this field . How accurate are satellite figures? It is important to note that the estimates offered by Climate TRACE are not the only ones, and they do not always match the results provided by other measurement methods. The Global Carbon Project offers a slightly lower figure for Serbia's total emissions: 42.36 million tons in 2023, while Climate TRACE estimates 63.02 million tons for the same year. The differences are primarily due to different methodologies, but also to the range of measurements. Perhaps the biggest difference is that Climate TRACE also tracks other greenhouse gases, such as methane, nitrous oxide and fluorinated gases. Next, Climate TRACE attempts to estimate emissions at the level of facilities and industrial activity, while the Global Carbon Project is based on estimates based on energy and fuel consumption, and their emission factors. An important note is that these figures fluctuate - although thermal power plants are always in first place, the rest of the top 10 changes somewhat from year to year, depending on the specific activities (as can be seen here: the text refers to the 2024 figures, the visual to the 2023 figures). The owners of our broadcasters and their policies HBIS , the 100% owner of Železara "Smederevo" at the group level, according to the Influence Map analysis , shows "limited" commitment and transparency regarding decarbonization, and the company's strategy is "mostly not aligned" with the Paris Agreement. Gazprom , the majority owner of NIS, according to the estimates of the Carbon Majors platform, is in the 6th position in terms of total individual emissions in history. This company is responsible for 2.32% of fossil emissions since the beginning of industrialization, which may be relevant from the perspective of "responsibility" for climate change. The same company, also according to the Influence Map analysis, does not generally support climate action, although it claims to work in accordance with the Paris Agreement. In addition to these international actors and their global supply chains, by far the largest share of greenhouse gases comes from domestic production and burning of coal, and action on this issue is imminent, but still critically overdue. We should also take into account the amount of emissions that are related to the use of motor fuels, Climate TRACE, for example. calculates emissions related to transport at the municipal level, with Novi Sad with 0.41 million, Palilula 0.38, Niš 0.27... The portal estimates that emissions related to road traffic are 10.91 million tons of CO 2 equivalents. In addition to the climate, there are also direct impacts on the health of the population related to heating plants, but also to transport, which is almost entirely based on fossil fuels. That there are a lot of tasks in the domestic yard is also evidenced by the fact that in 12th position (10th in 2023) in terms of emissions , the regional landfill in Subotica is associated with 0.42 million tons of CO 2 equivalents, while 0.28 million tons are associated with the landfill in Vinča (in total, waste disposal causes 2.33 million tons, or about 3.5% of all emissions). In addition to these largest emitters, the cement plants in Beočin and Popovac, in addition to local emissions of PM2.5 and PM10 particles, are ranked between 10th and 20th in this table from year to year. Here, it would also be relevant to take into account the broader picture of "upstream" and above all "downstream" emissions related to the further use of these materials in construction and infrastructure. Why is satellite data important? Climate TRACE provides estimates with varying levels of certainty, partly due to the quality of the source data "from the ground" (eg production volumes and technology), but provides an important complement to other estimates and calculations. First of all, this portal shows how important it is to have detailed and publicly available data and how important it would be for companies and local governments to approach emissions measurement and reporting in a transparent and up-to-date manner. The key questions for any climate action are "where" and "how much" . Otherwise, there is a danger that the policies are not properly directed and therefore not effective enough. What is particularly worrying is that according to Climate TRACE estimates, emissions at the state level are growing year by year, that in 2024 they were 4.7% more than in 2021 , which would be a movement in the wrong direction from the nationally determined contributions of the Republic of Serbia, as well as what is necessary to keep the warming within the framework of the Paris Agreement.

Article title: The goal of a "nuclear-free homeland" has been achieved, but the energy transition is still progressing against headwinds.
Full article text:
On May 17, 2025, Taiwan officially entered the era of a "nuclear-free homeland," a highly symbolic historical milestone. However, examining the actual structure of the energy transition, the originally set "50:30:20" (gas-fired, coal-fired, renewable energy) target was not achieved as scheduled. This reminds us that nuclear-free energy is only a phase in the transition, not the end.
 

 Looking solely at the Taipower system, the power structure from January to November 2025 was approximately 53% gas-fired, 27% coal-fired, and 13% renewable energy. However, if we further include self-consumption cogeneration systems and renewable energy generation under signed direct transfer contracts, the overall structure is closer to 48% gas-fired, 35% coal-fired, and 14% renewable energy. This gap highlights a crucial fact: the lagging progress in renewable energy development directly hinders the substantial progress of coal reduction.
 

 Against this backdrop, the Mailiao Thermal Power Plant plays a particularly critical role. Once hailed by some media outlets as a "savior after the decommissioning of the Third Nuclear Power Plant," the Mailiao Power Plant completed its decoupling at the end of this year, officially exiting the Taipower system. This facility, once ranked the 68th largest carbon-emitting power plant globally in the Climate TRACE rankings, has significant climate and governance implications in its shutdown, demonstrating that Taiwan cannot solely rely on "high-carbon replacement of high-carbon" to fill the non-nuclear gap.
 

 However, what truly warrants attention is not just the retirement of existing coal-fired units, but the structural risks inherent in the gas-fired expansion path. According to the analysis in the report "The Elephant Doesn't Want to Dance Yet," even assuming carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology can be commercialized as scheduled, the officially planned gas-fired power generation by 2035 will still exceed the net-zero scenario limit by 1.18 to 1.3 times; under a more aggressive renewable energy scenario, the gap could even approach two times.
 

 This means that under the net-zero transition path, the average capacity factor of gas-fired units will inevitably decline. Even based on official policy estimates, the capacity factor of gas turbine units is unlikely to exceed 50% by 2035, and may even drop to around 30% if renewable energy deployment accelerates. As for 2050, even with the full implementation of CCS or hydrogen energy, the overall gas turbine capacity factor will still only be around 43%.
 

 The problem lies in the fact that the environmental impact assessment for the new gas turbine unit in Mailiao is based on a 2400 MW installed capacity and an annual power generation of 17.8 billion kWh, meaning its capacity factor must be maintained above 84% for a long period. According to current net-zero policies, the actual operating life of this unit by 2035 may only be about 7 years, after which it will need to be significantly reduced, resulting in extremely high investment recovery risk and creating a typical stranded asset scenario.
 

 This is precisely the core contradiction of Taiwan's current energy transition: with the progress of renewable energy hindered, gas turbines are forced to assume an excessive transitional role, yet they cannot operate at high loads for long under the net-zero framework. Without a clearer exit and adjustment mechanism, gas turbines will transform from a transitional solution into a new structural burden.
 

 In summary, achieving a nuclear-free homeland does not signify a victory in the energy transition, but merely the prelude to the next phase of challenges. The energy transition is never a choice of a single technology or power source, but a systemic project involving investment recovery, industry risks, and governance capabilities. The key to the future lies not in how many more old problems are eliminated, but in whether we can establish alternatives sufficient to support a low-carbon structure. This path is destined to be long and costly, but there is no turning back.
